story:
About:

Starting October 2014 until July 2015, Limited Liability Company, a Limited Liability Company (aka Haitham Ennasr) will be exploring digital play within the context of contemporary Arab art at Ashkal Alwan’s Home Workspace Program. Your support for this project will go towards research, living expenses, materials, and equipment for that time period. The opportunity presented by being accepted to the program is exceptional, and being able to attend with your help will be instrumental in developing LLC LLC’s artistic practice, the result of which will be a body of work and research around digital play and game design.

LLC LLC is a Brooklyn based new media artist and game designer. His work focuses on spaces created through play and the documentation and representation of personal imaginaries. LLC LLC earned his MFA in Design and Technology from Parsons the New School for Design – New York, and His BSc in Computer Information Technology from the Arab American University of Jenin – Palestine. His work has been shown at the Museum of the Moving Image- NY, Baybycastles – NY, Parsons The New School for Design – NY, and the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor – MI.

The Lebanese Association for Plastic Arts, Ashkal Alwan is a non-profit organization based in Beirut, Lebanon. Over the past 19 years, the association has been committed to the production, facilitation and circulation of creative and intellectual endeavors across a range of disciplines and media.  The association has established itself as a reference within the cultural landscape of the region and beyond. In 2011, Ashkal Alwan launched Home Workspace, a 2000m² facility in Beirut dedicated to arts education and production.

As a thank you for your contribution, LLC LLC will be giving away prints from his last two projects, Emotional Labor and A Game of Shater Hassan. He will also be giving away digital downloads, prints, and paintings from his latest work in progress: Symmetrical Objects in White and Gold . Below are more details about these three Projects and the prints to be sent out for the different donation ranges.


Emotional Labor:

Chapter 1

Chapter 2


Emotional Labor is a project in which the normative qualities of relationships and friendships are reexamined through the lens of labor. The labor is documented as an archive of dates in which the artist, referred to in the projects as the writer, thought romantically about two other Palestinian men who also lived in New York. This archive is referred to as love letters, being that love letters are more or less the documentation of emotional labor exchanged between two people. The documentation that both men did not wish to pursue romantic involvement with the writer; it also shows the presence of labor beyond that point. The notebooks which held that documentation of labor were then sent to the men for them to sign, their signatures indicated the end of that labor, and the writer’s ownership of it.
The reclaiming, reenacting, and repurposing of labor, of emotional labor more specifically, is as much a question of what labor is as it is of how we interact with it as an object. This is especially true when the labor’s main presence in the physical world is documentation by the laborer. Would the labor documented in this project exist as an object that can be reclaimed, reenacted, repurposed, and indeed documented if not for the documentation itself? And how do we negotiate the representation of tangible objects that document entities that are as intangible as the digital, like labor?

The iPad app is available for free on App Store, click here to view it.



A Game of Shater Hassan:

A game of Shater Hassan was commissioned by Fuse magazine for their Palestine/Palestine issue.

The project itself is a nonlinear narrative that talks about oral history in the diaspora and about videogames and game design. The loops in which the reader is travelling from one block of text to another, and in which she is asked create blocks of text herself draw parallels from the write’s construction of an identity in the diaspora; partially remembered, partially researched, and partially fabricated.

It was printed as a two-page magazine spread and is available electronically on their website at:

http://fusemagazine.org/2013/04/36-2_ennasr




Symmetrical Objects in White and Gold (Work in Progress):

Symmetrical Objects in White and Gold examines an seven year old online friendship of the artist’s through visual semiotics.

An object, any object, is alway referential. That is to say that the independence an object is not possible. This is also true when objects are presented in isolation. For an example, when one thinks of a book, she draws from all of the books she has read, seen, and experienced to form her image of a book. It may be a leather-bound manuscript, a small paperback atlas, or an iPad with a PDF loaded into it. This kind of referential relationship will not only exist when thinking of a book or any other object, but also when looking at a book or any object. It will also exist if the objects we see are either abstract or non representational, our instinctive need to examine and interpret these objects depends on these referential relationships.

These relationships can be created by design, and they vary in volume. In this project they are created quite loudly is through symmetry. While other referential relationships still exist beyond the project, the relationship created through symmetry overpower them, giving each set in the project a false feeling of independence as an object.

The project is consistent of three main parts, the first is seven sets of paintings, the second is a series of postcards derived from the paintings, and the third is a digital game in which the paintings are recreated. The relationship of symmetry in each set of postcards is till more powerful than that of them and the paintings they are derived from, yet both the painting and the postcards affect each other as objects. In the digital game, the player recreates and examines these different symmetrical objects and patterns as way of investigating these relationships.

Set #1

Set #2

Set #3

Set #4

Set #5

Set #6

Set #7
story_txt:
About:Starting October 2014 until July 2015, Limited Liability Company, a Limited Liability Company (aka Haitham Ennasr) will be exploring digital play within the context of contemporary Arab art at Ashkal Alwan’s Home Workspace Program. Your support for this project will go towards research, living expenses, materials, and equipment for that time period. The opportunity presented by being accepted to the program is exceptional, and being able to attend with your help will be instrumental in developing LLC LLC’s artistic practice, the result of which will be a body of work and research around digital play and game design.LLC LLC is a Brooklyn based new media artist and game designer. His work focuses on spaces created through play and the documentation and representation of personal imaginaries. LLC LLC earned his MFA in Design and Technology from Parsons the New School for Design – New York, and His BSc in Computer Information Technology from the Arab American University of Jenin – Palestine. His work has been shown at the Museum of the Moving Image- NY, Baybycastles – NY, Parsons The New School for Design – NY, and the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor – MI.The Lebanese Association for Plastic Arts, Ashkal Alwan is a non-profit organization based in Beirut, Lebanon. Over the past 19 years, the association has been committed to the production, facilitation and circulation of creative and intellectual endeavors across a range of disciplines and media.  The association has established itself as a reference within the cultural landscape of the region and beyond. In 2011, Ashkal Alwan launched Home Workspace, a 2000m² facility in Beirut dedicated to arts education and production.As a thank you for your contribution, LLC LLC will be giving away prints from his last two projects, Emotional Labor and A Game of Shater Hassan. He will also be giving away digital downloads, prints, and paintings from his latest work in progress: Symmetrical Objects in White and Gold . Below are more details about these three Projects and the prints to be sent out for the different donation ranges.Emotional Labor:Chapter 1Chapter 2Emotional Labor is a project in which the normative qualities of relationships and friendships are reexamined through the lens of labor. The labor is documented as an archive of dates in which the artist, referred to in the projects as the writer, thought romantically about two other Palestinian men who also lived in New York. This archive is referred to as love letters, being that love letters are more or less the documentation of emotional labor exchanged between two people. The documentation that both men did not wish to pursue romantic involvement with the writer; it also shows the presence of labor beyond that point. The notebooks which held that documentation of labor were then sent to the men for them to sign, their signatures indicated the end of that labor, and the writer’s ownership of it.The reclaiming, reenacting, and repurposing of labor, of emotional labor
 more specifically, is as much a question of what labor is as it is of 
how we interact with it as an object. This is especially true when the 
labor’s main presence in the physical world is documentation by the 
laborer. Would the labor documented in this project exist as an object 
that can be reclaimed, reenacted, repurposed, and indeed documented if 
not for the documentation itself? And how do we negotiate the 
representation of tangible objects that document entities that are as 
intangible as the digital, like labor?The iPad app is available for free on App Store, click here to view it.

A Game of Shater Hassan:A game of Shater Hassan was commissioned by Fuse magazine for their Palestine/Palestine issue.The project itself is a nonlinear narrative that talks about oral history in the diaspora and about videogames and game design. The loops in which the reader is travelling from one block of text to another, and in which she is asked create blocks of text herself draw parallels from the write’s construction of an identity in the diaspora; partially remembered, partially researched, and partially fabricated.It was printed as a two-page magazine spread and is available electronically on their website at:http://fusemagazine.org/2013/04/36-2_ennasrSymmetrical Objects in White and Gold (Work in Progress):Symmetrical Objects in White and Gold examines an seven year old online friendship of the artist’s through visual semiotics.An object, any object, is alway referential. That is to say that the independence an object is not possible. This is also true when objects are presented in isolation. For an example, when one thinks of a book, she draws from all of the books she has read, seen, and experienced to form her image of a book. It may be a leather-bound manuscript, a small paperback atlas, or an iPad with a PDF loaded into it. This kind of referential relationship will not only exist when thinking of a book or any other object, but also when looking at a book or any object. It will also exist if the objects we see are either abstract or non representational, our instinctive need to examine and interpret these objects depends on these referential relationships.These relationships can be created by design, and they vary in volume. In this project they are created quite loudly is through symmetry. While other referential relationships still exist beyond the project, the relationship created through symmetry overpower them, giving each set in the project a false feeling of independence as an object.The project is consistent of three main parts, the first is seven sets of paintings, the second is a series of postcards derived from the paintings, and the third is a digital game in which the paintings are recreated. The relationship of symmetry in each set of postcards is till more powerful than that of them and the paintings they are derived from, yet both the painting and the postcards affect each other as objects. In the digital game, the player recreates and examines these different symmetrical objects and patterns as way of investigating these relationships.Set #1Set #2Set #3Set #4Set #5Set #6Set #7

story:
Bonjour,

L'association des étudiantes et étudiants en service social du premier cycle (ADESS) organise une exposition d'art permanente à l'École de service social de l'Université d'Ottawa. Les fonds amassés seront versés directement aux artistes qui participeront à l'exposition. Nous avons besoin de vous pour atteindre notre but de 5000 $ avant le 23 février 2015. Nous vous invitons aussi à faire circuler cette demande dans vos réseaux. 

Voici quelques détails relatifs à l'exposition:

Cette exposition se veut un rappel visuel et quotidien des raisons pour lesquelles nous avons choisi d'étudier et de travailler dans la profession du service social, tout en favorisant une collaboration entre différents milieux académiques et communautaires.

Le vernissage de l'exposition, intitulée Créer pour lutter: l'art au service de la résistance, est prévu de 14h30 à 16h le 2 mars 2015 dans la salle de conférence FSS4007, soit immédiatement après la conférence inaugurale de Dan Bigras pour le lancement officiel de la semaine nationale du travail social. Cette initiative a reçu l'approbation de l'École de service social, et du bureau du doyen de la Faculté des sciences sociales. 

Plusieurs artistes seront des étudiantes et étudiants de l'Université d'Ottawa  inscrits aux programmes de service social et d'arts visuels. Quelques autres artistes francophones seront issus de centres communautaires de Gatineau. À partir d'une banque de 20 mots relevant de la définition internationale du travail social (ex: justice sociale, résilience, équité, auto-détermination, etc), les artistes doivent s'inspirer du ou des mots qui les interpellent le plus. 

Nos partenaires pour ce projet inclus le centre de ressources communautaires le Lab (qui est rattaché au CIPTO), le Groupe de recherche sur les approches structurelles et l'intervention sociale dirigé par le Professeur Simon Lapierre, le département d'arts visuels, et le comité organisationnel de la semaine nationale de travail social.

En prévision du Congrès 2015 des sciences humaines qui se tiendra à l'Université d'Ottawa en juin, nous jugeons que le moment est opportun d'animer les murs de l'École de service social. Ces œuvres permettront de refléter le dynamisme et l'ouverture qui se dégagent de l'École. 

Nous vous remercions d'avance pour tout don que vous puissiez faire afin de soutenir cette initiative. 

L'ADESS

story:
Why We Do It:

BABY STEPS began as an experiment in maximizing joy:  joy in creating, joy in performing, and (hopefully) joy for our audiences. The act was born from a desire to find more lightness in a world that can feel unbearably heavy, and we quickly learned that this desire resonates with others. Our work theatrically channels messy experiences of being human through our alter egos Sherry and Terry, fraternal twins who have formed an adult contemporary band to inspire the masses. We've learned that we love creating space for a room of strangers to laugh together, and we're eager to bewilder and delight a new audience in New Orleans.

Who We Are:

We are Megan Thibodeaux + Andalyn Young, two performance makers based in Philadelphia, PA.  Our diverse backgrounds include work in directing, acting, dance, choreography, clown, mime, design, and some other categories we don't have labels for.  We've combined these influences to form an act that experiments with the conventions of cabaret and stand-up comedy, embracing a fiercely DIY aesthetic that values inventive creativity and wild imagination. 

How You Can Help:

1. Donating to this campaign: Any amount helps. Your donation will directly aid our journey to New Orleans in October. The big costs we are facing include travel, accommodation, rehearsal and production expenses. (There's also the rising cost of mustache glue and cassette tapes, but you probably know that already.)

2. Sharing: Spread the word of this campaign to others who you think may be interested in supporting our work. They say it takes a village to raise a baby, and this baby is ready to take some first steps outside of Philadelphia...

3. Caring: Rhymes with Sharing, but is a different step. Whether or not you have the means to donate to our campaign, your encouragement and support is of unparalleled value. To the friends, family, fellow artists, and strangers who have attended our shows and helped develop the work at various stages: we thank you for your time, energy, and love. We will keep making in hopes that you will keep laughing.

story:
Tenuous Connection is a meaningful collaborative project with artist Jowita Wyszomirska and curator Hyejung Jang at The Temporary in Baltimore, Maryland.

The combination of The Temporary's unique nature and Jowita’s delicate work lends itself nicely to the gallery's mission of  inviting community and creating connections. We are inviting the IndieGoGo community to support this project by making a donation to fund the artist's supplies and promotional materials.


Our Story + The Impact

The Temporary is a unique D.I.Y exhibition space at Maryland Institute College of Art (MICA) in Baltimore, Maryland. The Temporary will only exist until May 2012 when it will be demolished. In an effort to gussy up the facade, MICA took down the bricks of the old Graduate Studio Center building and put up floor-to-ceiling windows. This window space acts as a vehicle that engages the diverse audiences that exist at MICA as well as the surrounding neighborhoods.

Jowita Wyszomirska was born in Poland, immigrated to Chicago in the early 90s and is a recent transplant to Baltimore, Maryland. The experience of relocation, displacement, and immersion into a new culture remains the latent foundation of her work. With initial concern, Jowita creates her own way to relate herself to an alien environment. In her recent work, she starts with layering pencil marks, markers and lines of masking tape. These materials allow for more immediate connection between the space, the surroundings and herself. Mundane masking tape, her medium of choice, evokes a sense of temporality and fragility, where each deliberate line is at odds with its own impermanence.

Even though our collaboration is still tenuous, we are confident that the "Tenuous Connection" will be a valuable touchstone to creating a bridge between artists and communities. 


What We Get and What You Get

All of the money raised here will go towards the cost of materials for creating the series of site-specific installations and the printing of promotional materials. The installation of the project will take one week beginning Jan. 2nd, 2012. All are invited to come out and see the work in progress! 

As an appreciation for your support, you will receive an original drawing from Jowita and an invitation to visit her studio to see new work in progress.



To see more work, please visit:  www.jowitawyszomirska.com



Thank you for your support!

story:
RUN WITH RAS!

2016 marks the 3rd consecutive year  Riders Against the Storm has taken home top honors at the Austin Music Awards!  This was accomplished because of the village that continues to raise RAS.   Jumping off from our February RE:Mixtape release, SXSW, and an upcoming tour, we are gearing up for the next leg of our musical journey with you ALL!

On August 27 2016,  we are excited to celebrate two incredible milestones: our 3rd annual RAS DAY (headlined by Sun Ra Arkestra), and the release of 'Cornerstone,' our upcoming full-length album.  This record will be wailing with new sounds and songs that we literally cannot WAIT for you to hear.

Your generous contribution (at any level) takes our movement forward; and your excitement takes it higher. Yes, there are a list of rewards (below) that come with your financial pledge, but we would rather you invest in RAS once you’ve reflected on how much this beloved village has already brought to you and your family. 

In 2015, we were able to support 100+ different artists, small business owners, and non-profit organizations that have long been pillars of culture in Austin and beyond.  Our village can do more!  Let's get the more we are asking for!



RUN RAS RUN!

OUR NEXT STEPS TOGETHER

$7,000 powers us through the bare bones first phase of recording, mixing, and reproducing 'Cornerstone.'

  • $4,800 ($400 x 12 songs) to record/mix/master
  • $800 'Magik' (first single) music video shoot and edit 
  • $600 first run of 500 CDs
  • $500 for album promo photo shoot
  • $300 for album art/design

$10,000 powers all of the above, AND a publicist ($1,000/month x 3 months) to promote the record nationally.

$15,000 powers all of the above, and ensures we have the necessary financial backing to tour during the Fall/Winter (September-November).  This cost includes the production of new merch (tee shirts, posters, and accessories)

$20,000 powers all of the above, AND helps us to enhance the overall production of RAS DAY Festival, offering a secondary national headliner.


THE PERKS

  • $20 pledge - Early Bird RAS DAY (featuring SUN RA) tickets


  • $20 pledge - (1) Riders Against the Storm tee + (1) Digital Download of 'Cornerstone'


  • $20 pledge - (1) Qi Board Hand-made Fabric Earring set (styles vary) + (1) Digital Download of 'Cornerstone'

  • $40 pledge (RIDER) - (1) RAS DAY Ticket, (1) RAS DAY poster screenprint, (2) magnets, (1) autographed CD


  • $40 pledge - Two (2) Early Bird RAS DAY (featuring SUN RA) tickets.
  • $80 pledge - Four (4) Early Bird RAS DAY (featuring SUN RA) tickets.
  • $100 pledge (RUNNER) - (2) Early Bird RAS DAY tix , (1) RAS tee, (1) RAS DAY Screenprint, (2) Magnets, (1) Autographed CD, name included in CD 'Thank You' section.
  • $150 pledge (GLIDER) - Two (2) EXCLUSIVE High Quality Tees designed by Chaka, name included in CD 'Thank You' section.

  • $250 pledge (CHARGER) - (3) VIP RAS DAY tix (include complimentary drinks, meal, and access to VIP area), (3) RAS tees, (3) RAS DAY screnprints, (3) autographed CDs, name included in CD 'Thank You' section.
  • $500 pledge (SUN) - Two (2) EXCLUSIVE High Quality Tees designed by Chaka, (4) VIP RAS DAY tees, (4) RAS tees, (4) RAS DAY screenprints, (4) autographed CDs, name included in CD 'Thank You' section.
  • $1,000 pledge (MOON) - You/Your business name on all promotional materials, banner at RAS DAY and all of the perks of the $500 pledge level.
  • $2,000 pledge (MAGIC) - An original painting by Chaka, and perks of $1,000 pledge.


  • $5,000 pledge (COSMIC) - All of the MAGIC perks and a LIVE performance by RAS anywhere in the Southern region of the U.S.
  • $10,000 pledge (INTERGALACTIC) - All of the MAGIC perks and a LIVE performance by RAS ANYWHERE in the continental U.S.


THE TRUTH


OUR gratitude has no boundaries.

OUR music has no limits.

OUR community has no cap. 

Forward this to colleagues, friends and loved ones!

story:
Greetings and welcome to Dragon Bait Miniatures third Indiegogo campaign: The Krackatoan Warband.  The Krackatoans are a fearsome aquatic race of evil fish-men who dwell deep below the murky depths of a dark sea.  They are equipped with an array of formidable weapons and are known to be blood thirsty and savage fighters, ever on the prowl for unsuspecting victims whom they capture and devour.  Entire coastlines have been ravaged by the Krackatoans sudden and ferocious attacks . . . it is sometimes said they are accompanied by monstrous crustaceans whom they ride into battle like trained war elephants!  If your adventurers are looking for a new challenge - the Krackatoans have arrived!

The goal of Dragon Bait is to bring original, well designed and high quality pewter fantasy miniatures to the table top.  To help me in this quest I have had the good fortune to work with an exceptionally talented (and somewhat demented) band of rogues who all contributed to bring these amazing miniatures into being.  The veteran sculptor, Tim Prow, sculpted all of the Krackatoans.  Never did a more ferocious band of sea creatures rise from the murky depths.  Andy 'Beast Master' Pieper took on the formidable task of creating a monstrous giant crab to serve as the Krackatoans death-dealing battle mount.  The multi-talented Dave Soderquist, not only overcame diverse casting challenges in both resin and pewter, but also sculpted a truly enchanting mermaid, which is this campaign's reward figure for returning contributors.  Rob from Pennyfew painting did an amazing job bringing the Krackatoans and crab to life with his incredible painting skills.  Last but not least is Dr Mike Burns, a good friend and concept artist who's imagination helped get this project off the ground.



The Krackatoans were all sculpted by the talented Tim Prow and have been cast in a lead-free tin alloy.  The miniatures range in size from 28 to 32mm and are incredibley well detailed, each also comes with a separate pewter base.  The giant crab was sculpted by the very skilful Andy Pieper and is a large multi-part resin model which will require assembly.  The giant crab model counts as two packs of miniatures when selecting your perks.





Now those important questions about what we need and what you get:

  • The miniatures and the giant crab have all been sculpted and cast, so what do you need my money for?  The master molds have been made but additional funding would enable us to cover the cost of production molds and hopefully add a few more models to the Krackatoan line. Whether the campaign meets its funding or not all orders will be filled!  
  • How do the perks work?  We have a wide range of perks to suit all budgets from $20 to $250 giving everyone the opportunity to snap up some of these excellent miniatures.  The larger perks are an even better deal as the price of the miniatures is cheaper per pack.  Just click on the Contribute Now bar and select the perk that you want.  Please be aware that each giant crab model equals two packs of Krackatoan figures.
  • How do I let you know which packs I have chosen for my perk?   You can either send me a message through the Indiegogo site or an email with your selections.  You can do this right away if you know which sets you want, or you can wait until the end of the campaign and also select from any stretch goals which have been unlocked.
  • When will I get my figures?   It will take approximately 2 months after the campaign has ended before orders are sent out.  International orders outside the USA please allow 10-12 weeks for delivery, although in most instances your perk is likely to arrive much sooner.
  • How will my figures be packed?   The Krackatoan metal miniatures are sealed individually in plastic bags using a Grizzly heat-sealer.  This method helps to protect each figure and makes it more economical to mail out.  The giant crabs are multi-part resin models and will be packed in a box unassembled.
  • How much is postage?   For U.S. contributors postage is FREE!  The postage for International contributors is listed under each perk.  U.S. orders are sent out using regular US Mail.  International orders are sent by standard airmail.  Please be aware that if you want your perk sent by signed, tracked or special delivery this will be at your own cost.  Please contact me about the price of special delivery if you want your perk sent this way.






Stretch Goal figures are now available as Add-ons!

3 Krackatoan Crab Riders Add-on $15 each set


Krackatoan Sea Hag Add-on $5 each


All of Dragon Bait's previously released fantasy miniatures are available as add-ons to contributors of this campaign.  Dragon Bait's fantasy miniatures can be purchased at the special price of $5 each (unless priced otherwise) to add-on to your perk.

You can check out images of these miniatures on the Dragon Bait Website: http://www.dragon-bait-minis.com/shop/


SPREAD THE WORD!

The only thing left is to spread a few tavern rumors and pass on the word of this campaign to friends and family, forums and blogs, or perhaps even the odd podcast. Thanks again for your time and helping me bring more excellent 28mm fantasy miniatures to the table top.

Joe Corsaro

Chief Cage Cleaner

Dragon Bait Minis
story_txt:
Greetings and welcome to Dragon Bait Miniatures third Indiegogo campaign: The Krackatoan Warband.  The Krackatoans are a fearsome aquatic race of evil fish-men who dwell deep below the murky depths of a dark sea.  They are equipped with an array of formidable weapons and are known to be blood thirsty and savage fighters, ever on the prowl for unsuspecting victims whom they capture and devour.  Entire coastlines have been ravaged by the Krackatoans sudden and ferocious attacks . . . it is sometimes said they are accompanied by monstrous crustaceans whom they ride into battle like trained war elephants!  If your adventurers are looking for a new challenge - the Krackatoans have arrived!The goal of Dragon Bait is to bring original, well designed and high quality pewter fantasy miniatures to the table top.  To help me in this quest I have had the good fortune to work with an exceptionally talented (and somewhat demented) band of rogues who all contributed to bring these amazing miniatures into being.  The veteran sculptor, Tim Prow, sculpted all of the Krackatoans.  Never did a more ferocious band of sea creatures rise from the murky depths.  Andy 'Beast Master' Pieper took on the formidable task of creating a monstrous giant crab to serve as the Krackatoans death-dealing battle mount.  The multi-talented Dave Soderquist, not only overcame diverse casting challenges in both resin and pewter, but also sculpted a truly enchanting mermaid, which is this campaign's reward figure for returning contributors.  Rob from Pennyfew painting did an amazing job bringing the Krackatoans and crab to life with his incredible painting skills.  Last but not least is Dr Mike Burns, a good friend and concept artist who's imagination helped get this project off the ground. 


The Krackatoans were all sculpted by the talented Tim Prow and have been cast in a lead-free tin alloy.  The miniatures range in size from 28 to 32mm and are incredibley well detailed, each also comes with a separate pewter base.  The giant crab was sculpted by the very skilful Andy Pieper and is a large multi-part resin model which will require assembly.  The giant crab model counts as two packs of miniatures when selecting your perks.






Now those important questions about what we need and what you get:

The miniatures and the giant crab have all been sculpted and cast, so what do you need my money for?  The master molds have been made but additional funding would enable us to cover the cost of production molds and hopefully add a few more models to the Krackatoan line. Whether the campaign meets its funding or not all orders will be filled!  

How do the perks work?  We have a wide range of perks to suit all budgets from $20 to $250 giving everyone the opportunity to snap up some of these excellent miniatures.  The larger perks are an even better deal as the price of the miniatures is cheaper per pack.  Just click on the Contribute Now bar and select the perk that you want.  Please be aware that each giant crab model equals two packs of Krackatoan figures.

How do I let you know which packs I have chosen for my perk?   You can either send me a message through the Indiegogo site or an email with your selections.  You can do this right away if you know which sets you want, or you can wait until the end of the campaign and also select from any stretch goals which have been unlocked.

When will I get my figures?   It will take approximately 2 months after the campaign has ended before orders are sent out.  International orders outside the USA please allow 10-12 weeks for delivery, although in most instances your perk is likely to arrive much sooner.

How will my figures be packed?   The Krackatoan metal miniatures are sealed individually in plastic bags using a Grizzly heat-sealer.  This method helps to protect each figure and makes it more economical to mail out.  The giant crabs are multi-part resin models and will be packed in a box unassembled.

How much is postage?   For U.S. contributors postage is FREE!  The postage for International contributors is listed under each perk.  U.S. orders are sent out using regular US Mail.  International orders are sent by standard airmail.  Please be aware that if you want your perk sent by signed, tracked or special delivery this will be at your own cost.  Please contact me about the price of special delivery if you want your perk sent this way.












Stretch Goal figures are now available as Add-ons!



3 Krackatoan Crab Riders Add-on $15 each set






Krackatoan Sea Hag Add-on $5 each








All of Dragon Bait's previously released fantasy miniatures are available as add-ons to contributors of this campaign.  Dragon Bait's fantasy miniatures can be purchased at the special price of $5 each (unless priced otherwise) to add-on to your perk.

story:
Marx Project

My name is Mark Phillips and I'm an artist working in metal and adapting traditional printmaking techniques to metal working.  Back in February I started to develop a project using metal and new digital tools to make art and to bring to light Organ Donation.  In 1993 my Father died and his organs were donated.  Since that time I've often wondered about the people that received his organs and how I viewed this medical miracle. In our modern world the act of organ donation saves lives and in a very real sense extends the donor’s life as a piece of the donor lives on. This amazing feat begins by merely checking a box on a driver’s license for many; a simple stroke of the pen. Shouldn't it be more celebrated and illuminated in art?  I think so.


To bring this project to life I am building a CNC (Computer Numeric Controlled) Router to aid in the creation of the metal art pieces. The CNC Router (similar to the one in the video above) will be able to cut any complexity of shape following a computer generated file.  The plates will be cut much like a free-form jigsaw puzzle or stained glass window where individual pieces lock into one plane. The work will incorporate deep etched lines, subtle photo etched detail elements, engraved repeating patterns, enamels, patinas and bright anodized colors accentuating the work. 


My gallery in Chicago is open to having an event at the completion of the series in 2012 with an auction to benefit Organ Donation in Illinois.  Whether I reach my funding goal in 40 odd days or not, since IndoeGoGo allows for flexible funding, I am able to use all the funds raised to immediately buy parts needed for the CNC Router and complete the artwork.  The art show date will be scheduled once the router is up and running and the art pieces begin taking shape.


This project has been rolling around in my mind for many years but it has taken a long time to develop the skills and techniques necessary to execute the pieces as I've envisioned. Now I just need time and a little funding for materials to get the CNC built and finally move this project beyond my sketchbook and into reality.


Where it's Headed - The Build Blog - The Final Art Fabrication - The Show/Auction Benefit

My father was a machinist and as a kid I was always fascinated visiting the factory floor and watching him transform hunks of metal on a CNC milling machine and metal lathe into something beautiful.  I hope to instill that sense of wonder at witnessing the act of creation in my audience.  The public will be able to track the progress and watch videos of the router producing many of the parts and pictures of me assembling the pieces for the Organ Donation Show on the blogsite http://digitalmarx.blogspot.com/.





What the Project Needs to Get it Rolling

Computer aided production and assembly has been around for several decades in manufacturing yet only now are these tools within reach of artists. 

Here's a link to the CNC kit I'm building (example pictured below but mine wont be John Deere colors). I've already purchased the plans and the basic Hybrid R&P Router kit but there are a lot of things I need to get still. Play the video here, it's amazing.




My budget of $3420 includes: (some items have been amended as I have been able to purchase parts.  These items are offset and in bold.)

$665 Stepper motors, power supply and 4 axis drive kit
http://www.cncrouterparts.com/4-axis-electronic...


$270 3 Rack and Pinion Drives
http://www.cncrouterparts.com/rack-and-pinion-d...


$350 24' 20 pitch gear racks
http://mooregear.com/gearracks.html


     • $400 24' 80/20 Aluminum Extrusion ** Actually this ended up running $326 off

     of eBay shipped.  Delivered 8/4 Pics in Gallery***
     http://www.8020inc.net/2040-Pop-Up.htm


$175 Mach3 Cutting software
http://machsupport.com/


$600 Vetric V Carve Software
http://www.vectric.com/WebSite/Vectric/vcp/vcp_...


     • $700 PC Computer ***8/25 Someone has just donated a computer to the campaign,
     so I can mark this one off the list!***  I bought a monitor and keyboard/mouse
     yesterday (8/31) Computer works great and

     • $200 V-grove Bearings  *** Delivered July 28th see photos under Gallery tab above.  
     Actually these ran $257 shipped***
     http://www.superiorbearing.com/docs/guidewheels...


     • $60 2 start 8 Acme Worm Gear & Backlash Coupling ***Had someone donate an
     ACME worm gear they had as extra in their shop. It arrived 8/30*** 
     Ordered the flange Bearings ($16) from a guy online and they will be here next week. 
     Still need about $20 for the Backlash Nut but it's getting there.
     http://www.mcmaster.com/#acme-threaded-rods-and...


Subtotal 3420


Items I'll still need to purchase if there is any contributions over the target amount.


     • $122.42 Angle Iron - *** Had this delivered 8/10***

     • $100 Misc bolts, fasteners & parts  - ***Parts delivered today (7/29). 
     Good start to the weekend. :) ***

$250 Unistrut for table base

$65 2 sheets of MDF for cutting top

$200 Misc and shipping

$600 Aluminum Sheets


If I am short at the end of the funding period I will continue to buy parts and materials for the project.  I'm stubborn and will get the project rolling through sales of artworks and other endeavors til I reach my goal.  Any and all amounts contributed are going directly to parts and materials as they come in.  **Note the items above in bold have been purchased through funds raised from this funding campaign.  Thank You Contributors!  Incentives will be sent out as soon as they are completed and ready to mail.


Incentives 

I have various tiers of incentives for supporters from original prints, scaled mockups of some of the pieces in the series and even custom signage for those that may want something personalized and cut on the router once finished.  Please take a look through the perks and decide what suits your interest.

- To contribute please select one of the buttons are on the right side of the page.


You Can Become Part of the Project by Helping Spread the Word too!

Please help spread the word about this project and support if you can.  Please post a link to Twitter and FaceBook and let people know what I'm doing.  Use the Share Buttons for easy posting.

Thanks for Your Support!

Regards,

Mark Phillips

Blog - http://digitalmarx.blogspot.com/

story:
Short Summary

My name is Reed Black, I'm an illustrator and full time children's clothing designer. This project is one that I've had in my head since college and it feels like the perfect time to bring it out to really finish. I wanted to write a book for the children of cool parents. This story has a delightfully dark side to it as we follow a little boy who happens to be a zombie and who just wants to make some friends. You contribution will help me realize this project in a full color printed book and you'll be helping Zombie Boy make friends with more people than just me.

The book is already planned and thumb nailed with color studies and inks on the way. The goal is to have the entire project finished and sent to the printers before Momo Con here in Atlanta on March 8th.

What We Need & What You Get

I'm asking for $500 for this project, that'll cover the printing costs and little extras such as buttons, bookmarks and something special I want to do the the book's spine to give it an air of authenticity.My perks include your name in the book, copies of the final printing, personalized drawings, commissions and more. If we end up going over goal I'd love to make a 4' cutout of our main characters Zombie Boy and Cat.

The Impact

This is a project I could never do all by myself. I have a full time job that keeps me pretty busy but I desperately want to create things that I can see others reading and enjoying. Bringing this book to life (pun intended?) would mean that I have something to show as the various cons I am planning on attending this upcoming year and it'll allow me to work on more ideas for further Zombie Boy books.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spreading the word would be SO appreciated! There are tools here on indieGoGO that allow you to easily share this project on any of your social networks. It only takes a second and it would mean so much for this project.

story:
We Are Salt City Slam.

Jesse Parent, Gray, Courtney Hammond, JoKyR, and DeAnn Emett won the hearts of Salt Lake City, and were selected by the people to represent them in a tournament of epic proportions in Oakland, CA.

We volunteer our time by teaching workshops to youth regularly in detention centers and schools, 

We perform at charity fundraisers (Equality Utah, Revolution United, The Road Home, etc.), and festivals such as Utah Arts Festival, Urban Arts Festival, and the Utah Pride Festival.

We believe in the importance of spreading art through community and activism. The best way to do this is to prove ourselves successful in all endeavors, including the National Poetry Slam.  

We need your help to get there.

What We Need & What You Get

To attend Nationals, we have to pay:

Registration ($500)
Gas money for a 5 person team + coach
Hotel room(s) in sunny (but overcast in the summer) Oakland, CA.
Food, so that we can keep on top of our games and not starve.

For your generosity, we have a few perks we can send your way to show our appreciation.*

*If you would like a hard copy of the chapbook, please include an extra $5 or so for shipping.

The Impact

Salt City Slam is part of a larger project called Wasatch Wordsmiths, which is a new non-profit organization, promoting spoken word in Utah through youth outreach and activism. Being able to attend the National Poetry Slam will allow us to not only compete and show our talent and everything we've been working on, but will allow us to attend workshops that will help us better understand how to hold up a strong, supportive community.

Other Ways You Can Help

Attend our local poetry slams and other events.

"Like" Wasatch Wordsmiths on facebook for more information, schedules, and events.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Pawel Androsiuk and I’m a 19 year old aspiring Polish designer from Bialystok.


At the beginning of July, I got into the Royal Academy of Fine Arts in Antwerp.


For many years, I have been working very hard to achieve this goal. Unfortunately, my family is not able to fully finance my education in Belgium.

I've always had an interest in fashion, becoming seriously passionate about 5 years ago. The first step was to attend the patternmaking and sewing course in Youth Cultural House in my hometown, Bialystok.


Since 2010, I’ve been doing summer internships annually. For a couple of years it was at Maldoror Low Couture in Warsaw. 



Last year, I interned at Malgorzata Dudek Atelier in London.


I am constantly improving and honing my skills by taking part in different contests. I was the finalist of Young Fashion Day Competition and semi-finalist of OFF FASHION Competition.



One of my biggest achievements was being awarded a second prize in an international competition for a historical reconstruction of Helena Modjeska dress.



Apart from the pursuit of fashion design I was also involved in charity projects, supporting the non-profit organization such as The Grand Orchestra of Christmas Charity. As a reward for my involvement in this charity event I was chosen as one of two workshop participants who were given the opportunity to work on the “Tubakire Project” organized by the Christian Charity Service and ADRA Poland foundation supported by the Polish Foreign Minister. In relation to the project’s mission aimed at exploration of the value that lies in multiculturalism and humanity, together with the other participant, we sewed the traditional national Polish costume worn in the region of Kurpie, which was later donated for children with special educational needs in Rwanda. 



What I Need & What You Get


Studying at the Royal Academy of Fine Arts in Antwerp is the next step in achieving my dream and building a successful future. Please, help me up to fulfil it. I count on you and your support!

The first year of college costs about 15 thousand Euros. This price includes the tuition fee, accommodation, food, fabrics and other core study materials essential to study at the Academy.

I am aware that this is quite a large sum, however I strongly believe that you can help me collect the fund that would allow me continue my path.

I'm going to use my art to express gratitude in return for your support! I'm offering plenty of analogue and polaroid pictures (especially some new ones from Antwerp!), custom collages, drawings and designs!


Here are some examples:









The Impact

Thank you for stopping by. Every contribution made will be made the most of, helping me reach my goal. This is just a stepping stone, another hurdle that i must over come and its a goal you'll help me reach.


    Other Ways You Can Help

    I understand that some of you can't help me by contributing this project but it doesn't mean you can't help me at all! Please, use the Indiegogo share tools and make some noise about my campaign! Share it with your friends on Facebook and Twitter! I appreciate every kind gesture! Thanks to all of you!
story_txt:
Short Summary My name is Pawel Androsiuk and I’m a 19 year old aspiring Polish designer from Bialystok.





At the beginning of July, I got into the Royal Academy of Fine Arts in Antwerp.



For many years, I have been working very hard to achieve this goal. Unfortunately, my family is not able to fully finance my education in Belgium.
I've always had an interest in fashion, becoming seriously passionate about 5 years ago. The first step was to attend the patternmaking and sewing course in Youth Cultural House in my hometown, Bialystok.Since 2010, I’ve been doing summer internships annually. For a couple of years it was at Maldoror Low Couture in Warsaw. 



Last year, I interned at Malgorzata Dudek Atelier in London.




I am constantly improving and honing my skills by taking part in different contests. I was the finalist of Young Fashion Day Competition and semi-finalist of OFF FASHION Competition.





One of my biggest achievements was being awarded a second prize in an international competition for a historical reconstruction of Helena Modjeska dress.







Apart from the pursuit of fashion design I was also involved in charity projects, supporting the non-profit organization such as The Grand Orchestra of Christmas Charity. As a reward for my involvement in this charity event I was chosen as one of two workshop participants who were given the opportunity to work on the “Tubakire Project” organized by the Christian Charity Service and ADRA Poland foundation supported by the Polish Foreign Minister. In relation to the project’s mission aimed at exploration of the value that lies in multiculturalism and humanity, together with the other participant, we sewed the traditional national Polish costume worn in the region of Kurpie, which was later donated for children with special educational needs in Rwanda. 




What I Need & What You Get


Studying at the Royal Academy of Fine Arts in Antwerp is the next step in achieving my dream and building a successful future. Please, help me up to fulfil it. I count on you and your support!
The first year of college costs about 15 thousand Euros. This price includes the tuition fee, accommodation, food, fabrics and other core study materials essential to study at the Academy.
I am aware that this is quite a large sum, however I strongly believe that you can help me collect the fund that would allow me continue my path.
I'm going to use my art to express gratitude in return for your support! I'm offering plenty of analogue and polaroid pictures (especially some new ones from Antwerp!), custom collages, drawings and designs!

Here are some examples:















  The Impact
Thank you for stopping by.  Every contribution made will be made the most of, helping me reach my goal. This is just a stepping stone, another hurdle that i must over come and its a goal you'll help me reach.
  

  Other Ways You Can Help
I understand that some of you can't help me by contributing this project but it doesn't mean you can't help me at all! Please, use the Indiegogo share tools and make some noise about my campaign! Share it with your friends on Facebook and Twitter! I appreciate every kind gesture! Thanks to all of you!

story:
My Story

My name is Michael, and I'm an alcoholic and a drug addict. I've struggled with depression, anxiety and alcohol and drug addiction for over 20 years. The good news is that I'm now in recovery, and I'm currently 4 months clean and sober!

Coming out of treatment and going back to work, I quickly realized that my work environment was not a healthy one, and that I needed to make a career change if I was going to completely stay on track in my recovery. Right around the time I was realizing this, some very good friends of mine took me out to dinner to congratulate me on my sobriety and to catch up. I informed them of my work situation, and without hesitation, my friend Mark Mertins said to me "Don't ever think you don't have somewhere to go." Mark is the owner of a successful General Contracting company and a Custom Cabinet shop, and is a very talented woodworker. He invited me to come give him a hand at his shop if I needed some work.

Fast forward a few weeks, and I did in fact quit my job and was looking for work. What I anticipated to be a quick couple week temporary job at Mark's shop quickly steered me towards starting my own Carpentry company. I fell in love with the work, and Mark was willing to continue to teach me as we went along, so I could do contract work for him while also working on getting my own business started.

My reasoning for starting this campaign is to get my new business some startup funds by selling my famous Woodblock Keychains. I say "famous", only because this is an old idea I came up with all the way back in High School. I worked at a small lumber yard back then, and when it was slow one day an idea popped into my head to use the scrap cut-off pieces of oak to create Woodblock Keychains.

I made these keychains because I always noticed that when someone jinxed themselves and needed to "knock on wood" to counteract the jinx, inevitably the only thing around was some plastic, formica or other non-wood material. Now to those of us that are superstitious, this is not cool. When wood needs to be knocked there's a time limit to find it. (Roughly 15 seconds) My solution is the Woodblock Keychain. That way you have a nice jinx erasing piece of wood on you at all times. 

The Blocks

Part of my woodworking endeavor is going to be gathering the waste materials from large projects and creating unique custom items from them. This is material that would otherwise collect dust in the corner of the shop or end up as kindling. The blocks will all be handmade from recovered materials. These are the leftovers from very high end custom cabinet and furniture builds. The type of wood will vary depending on what I can get, but they will all be high quality.

The Impact

Because Mental Health and Addiction is so personal to me, I will be donating $1 from every block sold to a charitable fund that I will be starting called 'Building Recovery'. The idea is to start small and build funds to cover all the legal aspects of starting a charitable foundation. Once this is covered and Building Recovery is established, we can start raising more awareness and donations, and the main focus will be to create a enough funding to start a construction trade training facility that will give people returning to work after treatment a chance to come and learn a trade while working and earning a decent wage. I see and hear every day how finding skilled tradesmen is getting more and more difficult as time goes by. I want to give trades a boost while also giving people starting over a chance to learn new skills and make a living.

I want to do for others what Mark has done for me. I wake up excited to go to work and to learn new things. This opportunity has been so valuable to my recovery that I strongly believe, that if given the same chance, many others in my situation would thrive as well.

Full Disclosure

Yes, I am running a for profit business, and selling these items will benefit me personally. I'm not doing this as a boo hoo for myself, or using a charity to push my personal gain. It's quite the opposite. Yes, I need a new career and this is the launch, but I also want to help others while doing it. My company will continue to donate to this cause for as long as it is around, whether that be one week or 100 years.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't want any of the items, or don't have the money, but you would still like to help raise awareness for Mental Health & Addiction, then please send me a message and maybe we can collaborate.

story:
Kiki Smith's design for card back


PLAYING WITH A FULL DECK is an innovative fundraiser for the Greene County Council on the Arts’ Visual Arts Program. Original works will be exhibited in the GCCA Catskill Gallery along with a limited edition deck of playing cards, designed by a star-studded list of 52 artists with Kiki Smith’s custom design for the card backs. Take a look! These pocket-sized art collections are available for a limited time at $35. 


FUN EVENTS

OPENING
Saturday, January 18 from 4-8 PM, on view through March 1, 2013
398 Main Street, Catskill, NY 12414

CHARITY TEXAS HOLD 'EM  POKER TOURNAMENT
Buy a deck to play. Win lift tickets, spa days, golf rounds and more!
Saturday, February 8, 6 PM
GCCA, Catskill Gallery, 398 Main Street, Catskill NY 12414
Space is limited so reserve now.
Call 518-943-3400 or email gcca@greenearts.org to save your seat.  

AUCTION
Auction preview and silent bidding January 18 - February 28, 2014
LIVE AUCTION and closing party Saturday, March 1, 7 PM
Selected works from the exhibition


FUN THINGS TO BUY


POCKET SIZE ART COLLECTION
54 ARTIST DESIGNED POKER-SIZED PLAYING CARDS
IN A CUSTOM BOX (includes 2 jokers)
Edition of 500, 2 1/2″ x 3 1/2″ cards
   • $35 Pre-event orders- Purchases before January 18, 2014.
   •$50 Purchases at the opening event, January 18 and after.

54 ARTIST DESIGNED POKER SIZED PLAYING CARDS (including jokers)
ON AN UNCUT SHEET
Edition of 25
18" x 28", unframed
   • $35 Pre-event orders- Purchases before January 18, 2014.
   •$50 Purchases at the opening event, January 18 and after.

BECOME A NEW MEMBER AT THE $75 LEVEL
AND RECEIVE A FREE POKER-SIZE DECK

DELUXE  ART COLLECTION
54 ARTIST DESIGNED POKER SIZED PLAYING CARDS IN A CUSTOM BOX and
SIGNED, ARCHIVAL LIMITED EDITION PRINT
Your choice of one of the following card designs:
      Claudia McNulty, 3 of Hearts
      Hudson Talbott, 7 of Clubs
      Portia Munson, 10 of Hearts, 2 of Clubs
      Polly M. Law, Queen of Diamonds, Queen of Spades
      Mosa Tanksley, 6 of Hearts
      Erika M.Klein, 3 of Spades
8″ x 10″ signed archival print on rag paper, edition of 25
3 1/2″ x 3 3/4″ deck of cards
$100


PLAYING WITH A FULL DECK T-SHIRT WITH JOE STEFKO’S ACE OF DIAMONDS DESIGN

Men, Women S, M, L, XL sizes $35


Gallery sales and auction proceeds  are split 50% to the Greene County Council on the Arts and 50% to the artist.  100% of the profits from T-Shirts, Kiki Smith engravings and the limited edition deck of cards will benefit the GCCA Visual Arts Program’s exhibitions and services for artists including professional development seminars for artists and crafts people at all levels. This gallery serves as a cultural anchor on Catskill's Main Street hosting readings, youth arts events, lectures, meetings and partnering with artists. cultural organizations and community groups to add to the cultural vibrancy of the region.  


Help us spread the word!  Forward this IndieGogo campaign to your friends. Like us on Facebook. Tweet away!  #52PickUp. 

And let us know if you want to sign up for the Poker Party, or be on our mailing list for the auction. We are grateful for your help.  


Greene County Council on the Arts
398 Main Street, PO Box 463, 
Catskill, NY 12414
518.943.3400. 
greenearts.org
gcca@greenearts.org

story:
What is Cloud 9? 

Cloud 9 is a beautiful, functional interactive art experience for EVERYONE on the playa to enjoy. She is a mobile sanctuary for anyone she encounters, who might wish or need a plush, fun filled, luxurious ride on the playa. With a well appointed sound system, blankets and pillows for cold deep playa nights and whimsically gracious hosts, we hope to offer an experience that is nothing short of heavenly!

 

Who are the Geishas?

Geisha House has been providing a fur & velvet lined air-conditioned sanctuary with free flowing sake and a friendly welcoming vibe on the Playa, for over a decade. In 2012, we successfully brought our first Art Car, Cloud 9.  We are a small camp of hard working burners who pride ourselves in building cool shit for all to enjoy.

Why we need your help

We would love to bring Cloud 9 back for her second year on the Playa  To make that happen, we need your generous support for the following:

  1. Cleanng/maintenance of Cloud 9
  2. Repair of Cloud 9's lights - a good time was had by all in 2012 and she certainly needs a little post party love in preparation for 2013. We did not anticipate wear and tear on our lights, so this part of Cloud 9 will undergo re-design and renovation.
  3. Transport to and from the Playa.
  4. Fuel for operations on Playa.

The costs for the car, much of the materials to build it/pimp it out, the workshop/tools, the time, effort and love invested in building Cloud 9 was largely donated by the Geisha's in 2012. The cost to store Cloud 9 is also being absorbed by the Geisha's.

Why, why, and why? 

We believe Black Rock City needs fantastic art and fabulous Art Cars. So, we built one and we'd love to bring her back and share it with you all. 

Cloud 9 provides the opportunity to:

  • Be creative and whimsical.
  • Share and participate in community
  • Make and share Art, at one of the most unique events in the world

 

Thanks for your support. See you at Black Rock! 

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

Boner Remembrance Day© (or BRD for short) is an enchanted event thrown by the Badger's© to remember their friend, teammate and lover, The Boner.

(Disclaimer: Dave Bonaparte is still very much alive)

Overview

So here's the deal, ordinarily we hold the event in one of our backyards, but honestly, it's gotten to the point where none of our parents are comfortable with having a group of grown men celebrating a 'boner night' anywhere on their property. We see their point...

Doesn't matter though, we will adapt. We're moving to a venue. A classy as shit one. Problem is, we need your help...

What We Need

  • Money

It's that simple folks. Fact is, venues cost money. Money that a couple of twenty-four year old dipshits just don't have. What with that whole recession and the stock markets and you know, 401k's and Obama and stuff, we unfortunately don't have enough money to cover the costs ourselves like we usually do. Alas, that's where you come in...  

The Impact You'll Make By Helping

  • Your donation will help cover the cost of renting a private venue equipped with booze, music and food. 

We plan to make BRD VI as classy-- nay, classier than each of its predeccesors. By doing so we'll need enough money to lock down a decidant spot in either New York City or one of its fine neiboring cities (excluding Newark, of course). 

I assure you, your contributions won't go unnoticed and can really go long way.

The Impact You'll Make By NOT Helping

  • BRD will be cancelled

Yup. I hope everyone understands the severity of the situation. It's a hard pill to swallow, but the fact remains; venues are expensive.

"But Badgers, why can't you just spring for a shittier venue?", some of you may ask. Allow us to answer your question with another question: "How dare you?" This is BRD you jabroni, a no expense spared extraviganza that rivals Royal Weddings and Puff Daddy Parties. We would never disrespect Boner or his legacy by lowering our standards and half-assing BRD. You deserve better. We all deserve better. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Girls: Send tit pics to (201) 290-4937 to help keep us motivated.
  • Guys: Get a job then donate.

Conclusion

MacGruber video above says it all. We need your help folks. It's crunch time. Please purchase one of the perks to your right and help BRD flourish.

story:
Short Summary

To be Black, woman* and alive. Living at the intersections of gender and race, Black women, Black trans women, Black girls, and Black femmes are not protected or valued. As a community, it is our duty to create spaces where Black women* are centered, cared for and our voices are uplifted and heard. My name is Arvia Walker and I'm a visual storyteller and community organizer that centers my work on Black women and girls.*

#DearBlackGirl is a community-curated, love note-portrait project that is centered on cultivating joy, healing, beauty, and the magic of Black women and girls*. Together we will co-create a collection of love letters that are written by and for Black women and girls*. Alongside them, we will have portraits taken in a celebration of our magic. My hope is that this will be a community affirmation project where Black women* will feel loved and held.

These love note sessions will be provided free to community members in New Haven and Hartford in early Fall 2018. This is why your donation is so important. Any amount is appreciated and I thank you in advance.

*Black Women in all of our diversity and beauty are welcome. Women and girls are inclusive terms reflecting all those who were assigned and/or identify as a woman/transwoman/femme/girl.*

In Solidarity,

Arvia, Lead Creator

www.thecomingofthesun.com

 

 

Support & Pledge

What your donation goes towards:
I am hoping to raise $3,500 that will go towards the production cost of this project and events in the community.

This includes but will not be limited to the cost of the events which include renting of space, food and refreshments for participants, flowers, props made by a WOC florist, staging of portraits for participants, and production of the final collection of love letters and portraits.

Each participant in #DearBlackGirl events will also receive a free print with a love letter from the project.

$1-10 Good Vibes-Thank you for the support! We couldn't do this without you. You can follow on Facebook and see images and information as they are published!

$20+ A Lil Love- We'll make sure to give you a shoutout on social media for supporting the project!

$50+ Showered with Love-Social Media Shout Out & (1) Print from #DearBlackGirl

$75+ Flowerchild-Social Media Shout Out & (3) Prints from #DearBlackGirl

$100+ Bae-Social Media Shout & Free Final Product

$250+ Kindred Spirit-#DearBlackGirl Sponsor- Social Media Shout & name advertised at each event. This will include logo or name on an event board and/or information for a display table.

This project will happen even if we do not reach our goal, but to create the space that we are envisioning and that Black women* deserve we are asking for this amount to cover the cost of this project. If we exceed our goal, extra funds will be used to create more love note sessions in other parts of Connecticut.

The Impact

This event creates an opportunity for Black women* not only to be held but to celebrate their inherent beauty.

Each participant in #DearBlackGirl events will receive a free print with a love letter that will be sent to them to serve as a daily affirmation and reminder of the power that they hold inside of themselves.  

Other Ways You Can Help

SHARE! SHARE! SHARE! Tell people about this fundraiser.

Attend an event- stay up to date through social media

Facebook: www.facebook.com/thecomingofthesun or Zora: The Coming of the Sun

Instagram @thecomingofthesun
story_txt:
Short Summary
To be Black, woman* and alive. Living at the intersections of gender and race, Black women, Black trans women, Black girls, and Black femmes are not protected or valued. As a community, it is our duty to create spaces where Black women* are centered, cared for and our voices are uplifted and heard. My name is Arvia Walker and I'm a visual storyteller and community organizer that centers my work on Black women and girls.*
#DearBlackGirl is a community-curated, love note-portrait project that is centered on cultivating joy, healing, beauty, and the magic of Black women and girls*. Together we will co-create a collection of love letters that are written by and for Black women and girls*. Alongside them, we will have portraits taken in a celebration of our magic. My hope is that this will be a community affirmation project where Black women* will feel loved and held.
These love note sessions will be provided free to community members in New Haven and Hartford in early Fall 2018. This is why your donation is so important. Any amount is appreciated and I thank you in advance.
*Black Women in all of our diversity and beauty are welcome. Women and girls are inclusive terms reflecting all those who were assigned and/or identify as a woman/transwoman/femme/girl.*
In Solidarity,
Arvia, Lead Creator
www.thecomingofthesun.com  
Support & Pledge
What your donation goes towards:I am hoping to raise $3,500 that will go towards the production cost of this project and events in the community.This includes but will not be limited to the cost of the events which include renting of space, food and refreshments for participants, flowers, props made by a WOC florist, staging of portraits for participants, and production of the final collection of love letters and portraits.
Each participant in #DearBlackGirl events will also receive a free print with a love letter from the project.
$1-10 Good Vibes-Thank you for the support! We couldn't do this without you. You can follow on Facebook and see images and information as they are published!
$20+ A Lil Love- We'll make sure to give you a shoutout on social media for supporting the project!
$50+ Showered with Love-Social Media Shout Out & (1) Print from #DearBlackGirl
$75+ Flowerchild-Social Media Shout Out & (3) Prints from #DearBlackGirl
$100+ Bae-Social Media Shout & Free Final Product
$250+ Kindred Spirit-#DearBlackGirl Sponsor- Social Media Shout & name advertised at each event. This will include logo or name on an event board and/or information for a display table.
This project will happen even if we do not reach our goal, but to create the space that we are envisioning and that Black women* deserve we are asking for this amount to cover the cost of this project. If we exceed our goal, extra funds will be used to create more love note sessions in other parts of Connecticut.
The Impact
This event creates an opportunity for Black women* not only to be held but to celebrate their inherent beauty.
Each participant in #DearBlackGirl events will receive a free print with a love letter that will be sent to them to serve as a daily affirmation and reminder of the power that they hold inside of themselves.  
Other Ways You Can Help
SHARE! SHARE! SHARE! Tell people about this fundraiser.

Instagram @thecomingofthesun

story:
We are almost there ... help us finish strong!

Here are our standings as of 4:00 p.m. (CST): $4205 (on-line) + $2386.25 (in gallery) + $800 ("change" challenge) = $7,391.25  YES, that's right just $2,608.75 and we will meet our goal! Thank you in advance for the contribution you will make to help us finish strong!
We've got the dream; you've got the means!

Black Belt Treasures Cultural Arts Center (BBTCAC) has the opportunity to involve the community while restoring hope and strengthening the economic foundation in Alabama’s rural Black Belt through the arts - but we need YOUR help!

Our Story...

Black Belt Treasures Cultural Arts Center (BBTCAC) is on a journey to accomplish a dream - the establishment of a Black Belt Art House – Pottery Station, a creative educational space used to keep the rich culture and history alive, which the Black Belt region was founded upon.   

As we begin our tenth year as a non-profit, BBTCAC is proud to have a relationship with more than 450 artists and craftsmen from across Alabama's economically challenged Black Belt region, with visits from tourists from all 50 states and 23 foreign countries, and countless arts education experiences for youth and adults.  

   

Does our journey reflect success? YES, definitely! 

Are we there yet? No, there are many miles to go! 

Won't you help us complete this leg of the journey?

The Space...

The current BBTCAC campus includes a partially renovated car dealership; the renovated front portion is a beautiful gallery, office space, with limited teaching space, while the back portion of the facility (6500 sq. ft.) is the former auto shop and currently used as storage space (referred to by BBTCAC staff as the warehouse). 

Concept drawings have been prepared by Auburn University architecture students for re-purposing the warehouse space in order to provide artist work-spaces where they may work creatively while growing their businesses and developing unique products, and to allow for vibrant educational experiences (classes, workshops, exhibits, festival events, music, dance, and dramatic performances) for visitors, hands-on learners, and arts consumers. A portion of this expanded space will house our Pottery Station.

    

Alabama's Black Belt region has a strong arts heritage, including folk and Native American pottery, and contemporary artists - with the top selling medium and artists being ceramics.  We have chosen to begin our expansion with pottery because of its popularity, demand from consumers and tourists, and availability of qualified staff instructors to implement a strong educational program focused on ceramic arts.

What We Need...

We will form a Pottery Station complete with artist studio space, learning space, and equipment. Our ideal Pottery Station will include 10 fully equipped pottery wheel areas, a glazing station, and a minimum of two kilns for a total estimated cost of $25,000. While this is our dream, we are willing to start small and build as we grow. So our over all project will be accomplished in four phases. In Phase One, with your help, we will purchase four Brent Wheels, basic classroom tools and equipment, and enough clay and glazes to get started. 

As demand grows, future funding will be sought to complete the establishment of the “ideal” Pottery Station and ultimately the entire Black Belt ArtHouse.

Let us break down for you just what we need to get started: 

  • 4 Brent wheels
  • Pottery wheel work stations complete with stool, table, storage and tools
  • Canvas covered classroom tables
  • Drying racks  2 have been donated - Will now purchase a clay safe sink
  • Clay and glazes to get started

This will help us start teaching classes to the adult who has no access to equipment or tools, the youth who has little to no art classes in the schools, and the tourist who wishes to learn while on vacation. All of these will not only bring access to the learner, but will create a cycle of economic impact in one of the most impoverished areas of the United States. 

From small business opportunity to tourism dollars, the POWER OF ART will ignite change - all starting with your donation.

   

What's the Impact...

This project is about more than just buying equipment and re-purposing space. It is about providing opportunity for individuals of all ages and walks of life to enjoy learning a new craft, perfect their skills, build their portfolios, and potentially become entrepreneurs as they sell their works of art. 

    

BBTCAC is the centerpiece of an arts economy revitalization involving artist development and arts education located in the heart of Alabama's Black Belt. A region rich in cultural heritage, bountiful in natural resources and gifted, diverse group of artists, it is also one of the most impoverished areas in America. 

This ArtHouse will provide room and equipment that has not been available before. It will provide room and equipment for expanded arts education opportunities (classes, workshops), community arts presentations (theater, music, literary readings), and exhibits. 

The opportunities are endless as well as the potential in our community. 

This small expansion is the start to a new beginning and continued economic growth to the area; it is much more than just art. 

Join of us on this journey to mould opportunities for current and future artists!

What You Get...

  • Satisfaction - you know, that warm, fuzzy feeling in the cockles of your soul!
  • An assortment of BBTCAC logo items just to keep us on your mind and to show you how appreciative we are of you!
  • Handmade items made especially with you in mind by our very talented Black Belt ceramic artists.
  • Hands On experiences for you and friends in our re-purposed ArtHouse Pottery Station - a creative experience that will change your life forever!

"Celebrating our Black Belt Treasures" Signature Print of BBTCAC by Johnna Bush

Handcrafted Ceramic Mugs by a BBTCAC Artist
*these mugs are by Sam Williams

Handcrafted Pottery Bowl (or Platter) by a BBTCAC Artist
*this bowl is by Sam Williams

  

Handcrafted Folk Art Face Jug by a BBTCAC Artist
Autographed Copy of Alabama Folk Pottery by Joey Brackner

*Please remember that most of these REWARDS are one-of-a-kind handcrafted works of art - so each piece with differ in size, color, shape, and style...

It is hard to imagine, that we will not meet our goal BUT if that should happen, it will not stop us! We will simply adjust our plan and start smaller. IF we exceed our goal, we will celebrate joyously and then move ahead in our journey to Phase Two (5 more wheels, a new kiln, etc.).

What else can you do...

Share our Indiegogo campaign link. 

Tell your friends, family, and colleagues about ArtHouse Pottery Station; not only might they donate, but they'll learn about an awesome grassroots cultural center that is working to impact the economy and quality of life in Alabama's Black Belt. The more people who know about the work of BBTCAC the better the chance of making positive changes in the lives of the region's residents.

Please pass this email and link on to anyone you know who may be interested in helping us complete our goal! To make it easy use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
All funds raised will be put towards making the 2015 Boston Zine Fest a reality, securing venues, tables, and chairs, creating merch, providing food for exhibitors, and generally making the fest a fun & inclusive experience for all!

Please keep in mind that shipping is included in the prices listed for those in the continental U.S.! We've priced things to include shipping as well as IndieGoGo & credit card processing fees. All of your donations go to a great cause and we really appreciate it!


Who are we?

We're a collective of Boston-based zine-lovers who are resurrecting the annual Boston Zine Fest! We will be holding the second annual Boston Zine Fest this October on the 10th & 11th.

 In order to make this dream a reality, we need to raise $750 for our venue, food on the day of the event, printing/creating promotional materials, & providing for accessibility needs.

The BZF collective prides itself on striving to create a free, open-to-the-public, safer space, for zine creators and appreciators world wide to come together and exchange ideas, skills, and of course, zines! We are a not-for-profit collective whose primary focuses are promoting zine culture, and encouraging inclusivity within zine culture of individuals of all genders, races, sexualities, sizes, and abilities.

*All proceeds go towards the 2015 Boston Zine Fest, as well as ensuring that the BZF remains an annual event*


What's in it for you?

Help us put Boston back on the map as a major zine-city!
Encourage the creative cut-n'-paster in us all to keep on keepin' on!
Encourage & support DIY culture in the Greater Boston Area!

And of course, there are tangible incentives for donating to BZF such as
zines, artwork, BZF merch, & much more. Be sure to check out our photo gallery!


How else can you get involved?

Spread the word by sharing our IndieGoGo, Facebook, & webpage on your social media!
Attend a fundraiser!
Become a volunteer!
Apply to table!
& last but certainly not least, come hangout with us at the 2015 Boston Zine Fest on October 10th & 11th!
