story:
Short Summary

Associazione  di Promozione Sociale “ARCI RUOTI”

L’associazione nasce nel 2010 ad opera del socio fondatore Giulio Troiano con lo scopo di contribuire allo sviluppo culturale del Comune di Ruoti (PZ) , interessandosi principalmente alle giovani generazioni.

 Attraverso una programmazione mensile, l’associazione ha messo in opera diversi laboratori, attività ed eventi per bambini e adulti, anche con l’intento di mettere a confronto diverse generazioni (Carro di Carnevale, Attività ludiche per bambini, Giochi di società con premiazioni, Scambio-libro, Filmarci ed altro).

  Con tali finalità è stato creato l’evento multiculturale “Mostr’Arci”.

 

MISSION

INTERNAZIONALIZZAZIONE

Mostrarci è un crogiuolo di arti , artigianato, sapori e tradizioni del territorio, nel quale convergono anche esperienze trasversali provenienti da  tutto il mondo.

L’evento nasce come uno spazio aperto a tutte le arti, che mette in risalto le risorse culturali del territorio in cui viviamo, e che offre una possibilità di confronto  tra realtà lucane e  internazionali.

Nelle tre edizioni passate Mostrarci ha accolto artisti provenienti non solo da tutta Italia  ma anche dal Giappone, dalla Spagna, e quest’anno anche dalla Francia e dal Regno Unito.

 

TURISMO ESPERIENZIALE

Tutto il festival è organizzato in modo da coinvolgere emotivamente e partecipativamente la popolazione locale e i turisti, al fine di evidenziare come una partecipazione dinamica e attiva favorisce un miglioramento della vita socio-culturale e emotiva. L’evento è costruito secondo il principio dell’autoproduzione e della sostenibilità , concetti che verranno trasmessi ai fruitori in maniera pratica grazie ai workshop gratuiti, e alle pratiche di riciclo denominate  “Il rifiuto è un guadagno”. Gli spettacoli degli artisti di strada favoriscono ulteriormente la partecipazione attiva dei turisti.

 

CONCEPT EDIZIONE 2013

Il Festival delle Autoproduzioni e delle  Arti di Strada

L’autoproduzione è la caratterizzazione del festival, un principio messo in opera per uscire dalle grandi catene di business, partendo dai concetti di  chilometro zero, artigianale, biologico, biodinamico, di riciclo e riuso, e ecosostenibilità.

Le arti di strada sono state incluse perché sono iniezioni di creatività, gioco, espressione artistica, interazione e partecipazione, tutti concetti fondamentali nell’esecuzione delle “buone pratiche”.

 

OBBIETTIVI

Ogni anno ci siamo proposti di ampliare e migliorare il festival,  farlo conoscere a più persone possibili, sia per ampliare la partecipazione locale, sia per allargare gli interventi internazionali.

Gli obbiettivi dell’edizione 2013 del festival si possono riassumere nei seguenti punti:

  •  Espandere la portata del piano di comunicazione
  •  Ampliare l’offerta proposta al pubblico
  •  Offrire momenti di confronto e scambio esperienziale tra  generazioni, e tra persone con diversi background culturali
  •  Fornire spunti di sopravvivenza urbana (autoproduzione, riciclo creativo)
  •  Valorizzare il patrimonio culturale (centro storico, cantine aperte, sapori tradizionali)

 

ANALISI DEL CONTESTO

La politica culturale finora sviluppata nel territorio di Ruoti ha mirato a valorizzare il patrimonio  con progetti  che hanno attuato in maniera canonica una fruizione di tipo “tradizionale”.

In particolare nella Comune di Ruoti, sebbene siano state tentate azioni  di comunicazione non del tutto convenzionali, relative ad eventi e percorsi turistici, mancano ad oggi, progetti volti a creare una serie di ricadute sul lungo periodo. Tali azioni non presentando elementi di  ripetibilità e modalità innovative nella presentazione dei contenuti, sono risultate fini a se stesse.

Mostrarci invece ha già dimostrato di essere un progetto culturale ripetibile, rinnovabile e fruibile sul lungo periodo, creando un ciclo di continuità annuale. Tutti gli elementi  della rete creata durante la prima edizione (2010) sono stati confermati e via via integrati con i nuovi elementi nelle edizioni successive, perché chi ha partecipato una volta all’evento ha sempre espresso la volontà di tornare e partecipare nuovamente.

Buone idee e buone intenzioni sono alla portata di tutti, ma mezzi e fondi li hanno solo in pochi ed è per questo che serve anche il tuo aiuto.

 

Di cosa abbiamo bisogno e perchè:

 

Le nostre spese:

F&B...................................€  800

ARTISTI.............................€1850

AMMINISTRATVE.................€ 1150

ATTREZZATURE...................€  1550

PUBBLICITA'.......................€ 1400

I nostri fondi:

SPONSOR..........................€ 1200

LOTTERIA..........................€  750

INCASSI PREVISTI F&B........€ 1700

Al momento abbiamo un buco di € 2100 che speriamo di coprire con il vostro aiuto. Speriamo in oltre di riuscire ad avere maggiori entrate attraverso il F&B e la LOTTERIA, ma non è una certezza. 

In ogni caso se dovessimo raccogliere più fondi di quanti ce ne servono, questi saranno utilizzati dall'associazione per i laboratori che si organizzeranno in inverno.

Se invece non dovessimo raggiungere il budget previsto saremo indebitati e copriremo le spese con fondi personali nell'arco dei mesi successivi all'evento. 

Noi organizzatori non percepiamo nessun rimborso per il lavoro che svolgiamo nel organizzare e allestire MostrArci.

Già è capitato in passato di dover rimetterci con i nostri fondi personali derivanti dal proprio lavoro (quando c'è). Purtroppo è una condizione da accettare se si ha davvero la voglia di contribuire alla crescita del nostro territorio, giacchè le istituzioni locali non contribuiscono abbastanza.

Quest'anno contiamo su di voi e speriamo che il crowdfounding sia la giusta risposta alla nostra richiesta di aiuto.

 

Non potete contribuire? 

Sono tempi difficili e non tutti possono contribuire economicamente. Ci sono tuttavia molti modi con cui potete aiutarci a raggiungere il nostro obiettivo:

  • Fate in modo che le persone accanto a voi conoscano la nostra campagna

  • Condividete questa campagna su Facebook, Twitter ed in qualunque altro modoconosciate!

  • Parlate di noi ai vostri amici, fate conoscere il nostro festival a chi come voi ha a cuore la nostra causa e ha voglia di musica live gratuita!

  • Mettete "Mi piace" sulla nostra pagina Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/mostrarci

TURISMO ESPERIENZIALE
Tutto il festival è organizzato in modo da coinvolgere emotivamente e partecipativamente la popolazione locale e i turisti, al fine di evidenziare come una partecipazione dinamica e attiva favorisce un miglioramento della vita socio-culturale e emotiva. L’evento è costruito secondo il principio dell’autoproduzione e della sostenibilità , concetti che verranno trasmessi ai fruitori in maniera pratica grazie ai workshop gratuiti, e alle pratiche di riciclo denominate  “Il rifiuto è un guadagno”. Gli spettacoli degli artisti di strada favoriscono ulteriormente la partecipazione attiva dei turisti.
 


CONCEPT EDIZIONE 2013
Il Festival delle Autoproduzioni e delle  Arti di Strada
L’autoproduzione è la caratterizzazione del festival, un principio messo in opera per uscire dalle grandi catene di business, partendo dai concetti di  chilometro zero, artigianale, biologico, biodinamico, di riciclo e riuso, e ecosostenibilità.
Le arti di strada sono state incluse perché sono iniezioni di creatività, gioco, espressione artistica, interazione e partecipazione, tutti concetti fondamentali nell’esecuzione delle “buone pratiche”.
 
OBBIETTIVI
Ogni anno ci siamo proposti di ampliare e migliorare il festival,  farlo conoscere a più persone possibili, sia per ampliare la partecipazione locale, sia per allargare gli interventi internazionali.
Gli obbiettivi dell’edizione 2013 del festival si possono riassumere nei seguenti punti:

 Espandere la portata del piano di comunicazione
 Ampliare l’offerta proposta al pubblico
 Offrire momenti di confronto e scambio esperienziale tra  generazioni, e tra persone con diversi background culturali
 Fornire spunti di sopravvivenza urbana (autoproduzione, riciclo creativo)
 Valorizzare il patrimonio culturale (centro storico, cantine aperte, sapori tradizionali)

 


ANALISI DEL CONTESTO
La politica culturale finora sviluppata nel territorio di Ruoti ha mirato a valorizzare il patrimonio  con progetti  che hanno attuato in maniera canonica una fruizione di tipo “tradizionale”.
In particolare nella Comune di Ruoti, sebbene siano state tentate azioni  di comunicazione non del tutto convenzionali, relative ad eventi e percorsi turistici, mancano ad oggi, progetti volti a creare una serie di ricadute sul lungo periodo. Tali azioni non presentando elementi di  ripetibilità e modalità innovative nella presentazione dei contenuti, sono risultate fini a se stesse.
Mostrarci invece ha già dimostrato di essere un progetto culturale ripetibile, rinnovabile e fruibile sul lungo periodo, creando un ciclo di continuità annuale. Tutti gli elementi  della rete creata durante la prima edizione (2010) sono stati confermati e via via integrati con i nuovi elementi nelle edizioni successive, perché chi ha partecipato una volta all’evento ha sempre espresso la volontà di tornare e partecipare nuovamente.
Buone idee e buone intenzioni sono alla portata di tutti, ma mezzi e fondi li hanno solo in pochi ed è per questo che serve anche il tuo aiuto.
 

Di cosa abbiamo bisogno e perchè:
 
Le nostre spese:
F&B...................................€  800
ARTISTI.............................€1850
AMMINISTRATVE.................€ 1150
ATTREZZATURE...................€  1550
PUBBLICITA'.......................€ 1400
I nostri fondi:
SPONSOR..........................€ 1200
LOTTERIA..........................€  750
INCASSI PREVISTI F&B........€ 1700
Al momento abbiamo un buco di € 2100 che speriamo di coprire con il vostro aiuto. Speriamo in oltre di riuscire ad avere maggiori entrate attraverso il F&B e la LOTTERIA, ma non è una certezza. 
In ogni caso se dovessimo raccogliere più fondi di quanti ce ne servono, questi saranno utilizzati dall'associazione per i laboratori che si organizzeranno in inverno.
Se invece non dovessimo raggiungere il budget previsto saremo indebitati e copriremo le spese con fondi personali nell'arco dei mesi successivi all'evento. 
Noi organizzatori non percepiamo nessun rimborso per il lavoro che svolgiamo nel organizzare e allestire MostrArci.
Già è capitato in passato di dover rimetterci con i nostri fondi personali derivanti dal proprio lavoro (quando c'è). Purtroppo è una condizione da accettare se si ha davvero la voglia di contribuire alla crescita del nostro territorio, giacchè le istituzioni locali non contribuiscono abbastanza.
Quest'anno contiamo su di voi e speriamo che il crowdfounding sia la giusta risposta alla nostra richiesta di aiuto.
 



Non potete contribuire? 
Sono tempi difficili e non tutti possono contribuire economicamente. Ci sono tuttavia molti modi con cui potete aiutarci a raggiungere il nostro obiettivo:


Fate in modo che le persone accanto a voi conoscano la nostra campagna


Condividete questa campagna su Facebook, Twitter ed in qualunque altro modoconosciate!


Parlate di noi ai vostri amici, fate conoscere il nostro festival a chi come voi ha a cuore la nostra causa e ha voglia di musica live gratuita!


Mettete "Mi piace" sulla nostra pagina Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/mostrarci

story:
HOUSE 2015 needs your help to transform unusual and unexpected spaces into our events venues.  Most dramatically we want to convert a derelict old wood yard into our pop-up cinema so we can show a programme of rarely seen films of protest.

The idea for the HOUSE 2015 cinema programme evolved out of the theme Edge and Shift, introduced by this year’s lead artist Nathan Coley. His new commission Portraits of Dissension looks at links between the destruction and renovation of architecture in the aftermath of political acts, and how we manifest answers physically in the world.

In the face of dissension, protest often provides the necessary edge that leads to change.  The Cinema of Re-Enactment grew out of these themes and through collaboration with Cinecity we put together a season of films spanning seven decades of cinematic history. 

The programme will include Jeremy Deller and Mike Figgis’ Battle of Ogreave, Peter Watkins’ Culloden, Humprey Jennings’ Silent Village, the astonishing Indonesian film The Act of Killing, local archive footage and two artist shorts that inspired the work of some HOUSE 2015 artists.

Other highlights will include an In Conversation with lead artist Nathan Coley in the oldest building in Brighton and exhibition tours of The Regency Town House.

We are asking for your support to help us prepare these venues, supply seating, heating, lights and more – to make this the most unusual Events programme and Pop-up Cinema yet experienced.

Please support our campaign.

HOUSE 2015 events run from 14th - 17th May, please see further details here.

housefestival.org

story:
We Are SNAG!

The Society of North American Goldsmiths is a nonprofit organization that advances jewelry and metalsmithing by inspiring creativity, encouraging education, and fostering community.

Founded in 1969, SNAG has grown from 64 original members to more than 3,000 studio artists, educators, students and others working in various metals, alternative materials, and all aspects of contemporary art, design, jewelry and metalsmithing. Through education, innovation, and leadership, SNAG provides access to a vibrant and passionate community.

The recession has been especially hard on artists, both personally and professionally. SNAG has not been immune to it either. We have been working hard to change our business model to lessen our reliance on one form of income, streamline our costs, and to create greater impact with the resources we do have. Despite the hard economic times, SNAG has become leaner and stronger, continuing to offer programs, opportunities, and scholarships to its membership. 

 

In the 2014 Craft Emergency Relief Fund (CERF+) Sustaining Careers Report found the largest group of craft artists received less than $10,000 in gross revenue from their craft business in 2013. 

By supporting and sharing our campaign, you are helping to ensure the future of SNAG. Your investment in SNAG, no matter the size, will allow us to continue advancing artists, supporting students and validating our field. Your gift will make a mark in the life of an artist and support our community of creative problem solvers.

Expanding Our Impact

Offer more programs, teach more youth, and build more community!

In the next few years, SNAG will be revitalized through a variety of new initiatives. We will be developing new partnerships to increase our impact.  Working with like-minded organizations, we learn more and get to share our passion with a wider audience. We are creating an exciting new program model to offer you more options and new ways to access the SNAG community. (YOUR community!)  We will be providing new platforms for stimulating and thoughtful conversations that will propel the field.  Cultivating these stirring discussions will expand our thinking and invigorate our work. 

SNAG will enrich our community by expanding scholarship offerings, sponsorships, and exhibitions.  These new opportunities will support the professional practices of artists and enable them to interact with their communities in dynamic and meaningful ways.

SNAG supports our makers through:

  • Metalsmith magazine

  • Annual Gatherings - Conferences or the new Alt-Cons

  • Critical Conversations Convenings

  • Road 2 Success Entrepreneurship Program

  • Professional Development Seminars

  • Exhibitions

  • Sales

  • Maker Profiles

  • Scholarships

  • And much more!


Meet your Fellow Makers

SNAG is a tribe, a creative community of artists, designers, makers, teachers, collectors, curators, historians, patrons, and the curious. We are united by our ability to see potential, our desire to make, and our dedication to our community.

Our video gave you a quick glance at just a few of the artists that make up SNAG. To learn more about the many diverse people in our organization and see some of the beautiful work they create, visit our website at  www.SNAGmetalsmith.org.


Perk Details!

$10 - Thank you! We’ll thank you with a Facebook shout out.  You will also be entered into a drawing for a free basic conference registration at the 2015 SNAG conference in Boston. Oh, and a “Smiths Do It Better” sticker is headed your way! (Qty 250)

$25 - Hand File Level:  Facebook shout out, entry into drawing for a free basic conference registration at the 2015 SNAG conference in Boston, a “Smiths Do It Better” sticker, AND a SNAG notepad. (Qty 100)

$50 - Hammer Level: In addition to a Facebook shout out, a “Smiths Do It Better” sticker, and entry into the conference drawing, you will receive a bronze hammer pin designed by metalsmith and designer Sunyoung Cheong. (These won’t last!) (Qty 50)

$100 - Flex Shaft Level: All the perks of the $50 level plus a limited edition, SNAG Poster for you posting pleasure! (qty 30)

$250 -Anvil Level: All the perks of the $50 level plus a swanky recycled cotton, made in USA messenger bag! (Qty 20)

$500 - Beautiful, handmade jewelry. Our specialty! We invited 22 artists to create a unique, handmade brooch or pair of earrings. You are now invited to take your pick!  (First come, first serve!)  You will also received a Facebook shout out, a “Smiths Do It Better” sticker, bronze hammer pin, and entry into the 2015 conference drawing. Interested? Take a look at the amazing work at http://www.snagspace.org/join-the-movement/ and  email Anne Fiala at amfiala@snagmetalsmith.org with your selection. (Qty 22)


Other ways you can help!

  • Get Involved: We need all the help we can get to ensure SNAG’s dynamic future! You don’t have to be a metalsmith to help! Sign up to volunteer with us by email our volunteer coordinator at volunteercoordinator@snagmetalsmith.org

  • Share this project with your friends, family, and network! The more people we can reach the better - thank you for spreading the word! Use the Indiegogo share button to connect with your social networks.

  • In-Kind Support:  Donate an item to the 2015 Silent Auction taking place at the Boston conference.

  • AmazonSmile: AmazonSmile is a simple and automatic way for you to support SNAG every time you shop, at no cost to you. When you shop at smile.amazon.com, you’ll find the exact same low prices, vast selection and convenient shopping experience as Amazon.com, with the added bonus that Amazon will donate a portion of the purchase price to your favorite charitable organization.

story:
Short Summary

  • Grand Circus Magazine is the work of Alex Trajkovski and Eileen Tjan, a pair of graphic designers originally from Michigan.
  • Grand Circus Magazine is a beautifully designed publication helping to spread the word about contemporary Detroit culture in an effective and engaging way. The city already has its hard-news and newsprint weeklies, but lacks a real lifestyle magazine detailing Detroit urbanism. This matte and gloss edition, with gold foil and embossing is perfect bound and ready for display on coffee tables.


  • By contributing, you can help us achieve the printing of our premiere issue, with an emphasis on quality design and content. 

What We Need & What You Get

Here's how it breaks down in more detail:

  • We need 8.5k for the printing of 500 copies.
  • If you contribute $5, we will send you a Grand Circus sticker
  • If you give $10, you will receive a handmade Grand Circus bookmark and a sticker! The bookmarks are being hand printed and various artists/designers/illustrators from around the country are contributing to provide some Detroit-centric designs! 
  • For $25, you get a sticker, the BOOKMARK SET, and a digital pdf of the magazine!
  • For $50, you get all the above and a copy of the magazine.
  • If you can give $100 or more, you get all the above and your name will be listed in the magazine!
  • If you give $500 or more, you get all the above and you and a +1 will be specially invited as our VIP guests to our launch party. Special treatment tba. :)
  • If you give $1000 or more, you get all of the above perks, the 2nd issue free, and Other Studio will do a design project for you.

The Perk Artwork

Designed and illustrated from some of the best in the industry, in return for your donations we will be turning these pieces of art into bookmarks and possibly art prints! We'll send a little bit of Detroit to you!


The Impact

The reason this project is so valuable is because such a consequential city has never had such a large void. Our mission is to repair the stigmatized name of the city, create a cultural resource for the metro region, and export the finer aspects of Detroit culture from coast to coast. The magazine is a vessel for collaboration and a stimulator for creation. 

Risks & Challenges

We already have designed, edited, and labored over our first issue! Many talented people have been involved with this first issue. Now is the time to raise the funds to release it! Without your support we can't complete what took almost a year to source and design. One of our greatest challenges is keeping printing quality high and keeping the price of the magazine affordable.


Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute toward our printing, that doesn't mean you can't help! Please help spread the word about Grand Circus Magazine!

Our website and future store is ReadGrandCircus.com. 

Follow us on social media: facebook.com/readgrandcircus

On instagram @_grandcircus.

Or, share this Indiegogo to your social network.

story:
Dear you,

Here are 10 things I know to be true:

1.  This year (2014) I turn 30.

2.  My mom is Sally, my dad Matt.

3.  I’ve been in love three times.

4.  I am afraid to fail (at what? Most things).

5.  I am alive.

6.  Money scares me.

7.  One year is just enough time.

8.  My body is asymmetrical.

9.  Only one of my nails has polish on it.

10. Everyone and every place has history.

For this project I am attending an art residency in Otranto, Italy from June 15 – 30th, 2014 during which I’ll be collecting documentation of the personal histories of the people I encounter while considering my self as a conduit for storytelling. History is a vast subject, and human history spans an array of cultures and time periods. It is due to our desire to learn, remember and preserve the past that we find ways to do so in the present. I'm wondering, does it matter if the stories people tell are a mixture of fact and embellishment? Or, is what matters the moment when we sit down together and  share our stories?

With the collected documentation (video, written, photographed, and drawn) a series of short films will be created upon my return to Santa Barbara in a collaboration with the exhibition Marinella Senatore. Building Communities on view from May 10 - August 17, 2014 at the Museum of Contemporary Art Santa Barbara. At the museum I will utilize three open platforms provided by the museum - a creative writing workshop space, a dance floor, and a movie set - to produce the films.

What you are paying for by donating:

Travel costs to and from Otranto, Italy – $2,000

Cost of the residency – $1,450

Fees for campaign management (Indiegogo) - $250

Hoping this sparks interest in the history of you,

Sophie

http://youandsophie.com/

story:
Short Summary

'Living in Auschwitz' started as a news reporting story for the Belgian national broadcaster VRT. In a 25 minute long version we explore how the inhabitants of the Polish town of Oświęcim experience the closeness of the former Auschwitz concentration camp. 

 During our work, we have encountered a variety of attitudes towards the place among both the inhabitants and visitors, among them articulating the trauma and uneasiness, silencing it, expressing disappointment, or finding a source of entertainment in discovering the physical remainders of the past. While the proximity of the memorial site can lead to positive outcomes, such as peace work, it can also provoke more disturbing approaches like rising anti-semitism or transformation of camps into tourist attractions.

The 25 minute version of the documentary will be broadcasted on Belgian national television in mid-May. But to reach out to wider audiences outside of Belgium, we want to make a 45 minute expanded version of 'Living in Auschwitz'. This version would be used for screenings on festivals and in museums, cultural centres, as well as for educational workshops at universities and high schools. The funds gathered through a crowd funding  campaign will be used to cover the editing costs of a longer film.

Risks & Challenges

The fact that all the material has already been recorded reduces the risks. Once the edit is funded we will plan two weeks with an editor to do the work. No serious obstacles are expected.

'Living in Auschwitz' started as a news reporting story for the Belgian national broadcaster VRT. In a 25 minute long version we explore how the inhabitants of the Polish town of Oświęcim experience the closeness of the former Auschwitz concentration camp. 

 During our work, we have encountered a variety of attitudes towards the place among both the inhabitants and visitors, among them articulating the trauma and uneasiness, silencing it, expressing disappointment, or finding a source of entertainment in discovering the physical remainders of the past. While the proximity of the memorial site can lead to positive outcomes, such as peace work, it can also provoke more disturbing approaches like rising anti-semitism or transformation of camps into tourist attractions.
The 25 minute version of the documentary will be broadcasted on Belgian national television in mid-May. But to reach out to wider audiences outside of Belgium, we want to make a 45 minute expanded version of 'Living in Auschwitz'. This version would be used for screenings on festivals and in museums, cultural centres, as well as for educational workshops at universities and high schools. The funds gathered through a crowd funding  campaign will be used to cover the editing costs of a longer film.

    Risks & Challenges The fact that all the material has already been recorded reduces the risks. Once the edit is funded we will plan two weeks with an editor to do the work. No serious obstacles are expected.

story:
Un, une parmi plusieurs autres.

Les images sélectionnées pour cette première édition naissent de relations entretenues depuis une dizaine d'années.
Des images qui sont habituellement cachées aux regards étrangers seront ici exposées, divulguées.
Des sujets photographiés jusqu'au choix de l'imprimerie parisienne, en passant par le graphisme, le livre se révèle comme une multitude d'amitiés.
**
One amongst the others.
The pictures selected for this first edition spring from relationships panning a dozen years.
Pictures which are usually hidden from foreign looks will be exposed and exhibited.
From the subjects chosen, to the style of the book, or to the Parisian printing house, this book presents itsef as a collection of friendships.


La photographie des proches apparaît à la toute fin des années 1970 et se développe dans les années 1980. Héritière de la photographie de famille, elle regroupe des artistes qui, témoignant des transformations sociales et morales modernes, s'en emparent et les montrent. Les images qu'ils proposent au public naissent de leurs milieux, de leurs relations ; elles interrogent les notions très hétéronormées de l'intimité, de la sexualité, du genre. Une nouvelle transparence et la liberté de dévoiler ce qui fait et ce qu'est le privé se cristallisent lorsque des artistes comme Clark, Goldin et Tillmans décident de montrer ce qui jusqu'alors était caché : l'intime. Leurs proches comme sujet, leur quotidien comme temporalité rendent compte d'une nouvelle façon de penser la photographie – elle n'est plus un souvenir, elle est la relation. C'est dans ce genre photographique que j'ai développé ma pratique. La diffusion par le biais d'un petit livre entre les mains du regardeur tente de recréer ce lien intime qui me lie avec mes sujets photographiés. Des sujets photographiés jusqu'au choix de l'imprimerie parisienne, en passant par le graphisme, le livre se révèle comme une multitude d'amitiés. 
**
Choosing close friends as subjects became a trend in photography in the late 1970s, which at first borrowed the codes of family pictures, and developed further in the 1980s. Artists witnessed the social and moral transformations of the times, and gathered together to take hold of them and display them. They took images from their background and their relationships and showed them to the world to question the heteronormative notions of intimacy, sexuality, and gender. Artists such as Clark, Goldin, and Tillmans decided to show what was hidden until then – intimacy – and gave shape to a new transparency, and to the freedom to unveil what defines private life. Their subjects (their closest friends) and their temporality (their daily life) describe a new way to think photography – not as a memory, but as the relationship itself. My practice has evolved within this photographic genre. Releasing a little book that can find its place in the hands of the viewer is for me a way to recreate the intimate link between my subjects and me. From my subjects to the style of the book, or to the Parisian printing house, this book presents itself as a collection of friendships.

story:
Ceramics Experience

   When I was in high school, I took my first ceramics class. I found that ceramics was the first artistic outlet where my creativity blossomed. I practiced for two years, taking all of the levels offered, including hand-building and a sculpture class. Before my senior year, the ceramic professor kindly created an Advanced Ceramics class for a group of very eager ceramic-loving students, including myself, who had already taken all of his classes. This class was very free-style, consisted primarily of wheel throwing and occasional lecture. My first raku, horse hair, firing was in this class. 
   During my very busy college years, I hadn't had the opportunity of taking another ceramics class. Currently, now that I'm feeling settled down from graduating and getting into the flow of the working life, I decided to take a ceramics class with a good friend. This was mainly a treat for myself during the dark, chilly days of winter and to re-establish a former passion. As I hoped, centering the damp clay beneath my grip was ingrained in my muscle memory. 
   This beginners class is taught by Jeremy Ayers through Burlington City Arts (BCA) at the Main Street Clay Studio. After relearning old techniques I had once known, learning new techniques and surrounding myself with inspirational ceramic artists, my 8-week class is coming to a close. As I am still practicing glazing and my mind is flowing with more education and ideas on how to improve my pottery skills, I've realized that I need to continue practicing ceramics. 

The Next Step and How You Can Help

   My spirit has been jumping for joy and taking this class has opened up a door of growing excitement that I do not want to close again. The mindfulness of the art of wheel throwing has made me very excited, it has centered my well being, encouraged my creativity and put me more at peace with stresses in my life. Ceramics has given me an opportunity to do something on my own, branch out with other people of the community and feel more apart of Burlington. In many ways, it's extremely important to many aspects of my life. 
   My plan is to rent studio space during this summer, until the next level ceramics class is offered. This is likely 3-6 months until the next class. The fall / winter class schedules have not been posted yet but they do happen at least once annually. I'm not sure what other modalities are like, but I have found that ceramics cost a little bit more than I can afford currently. Below is the BCA's rent rates and benefits of a studio space: 

STUDIO RATES

Clay Studio rental costs $55 per month with discounts available for the purchase of rental in 3, 6 and 12 month increments.

- 1 month - $55 
- 3 months - $148.50 (10% off) 
- 6 months - $280.50 (15% off) 
- 1 year - $528 (20% off) 

All rentals due on the 1st of the month. Any new renters will be prorated $1.50/day if they join in the middle of the month to start them on the 1st of the month cycle. 

STUDIO BENEFITS

- Use of wheels, slab roller, extruder and facilities
- More than 20 studio hours per week, many on weekends
- Storage space for work and supplies
- Opportunities to exhibit work

Studio hours change monthly based on class schedules. The Clay Studio is open to the public Monday-Friday, 9am-5pm for studio tours, inquiries, and to pick up work. Call the studio at 802.860.7474 for more information.

My Goals

   This website will only allow me to put $500 dollars for a minimum goal. As you see from the rates above, $528 could get me an entire year of ceramics studio space! This is not my goal. My goal is to rent space until a class is offered. Although it would be great, I just need funding for 3-6 months ($148.50 - $270.50).  If this goal is not reached, I can still use your generous gifts towards rent for the studio space. If this goal is reached or fulfilled beyond $500, the extra donations will be used towards the class that I am saving up for or more studio rent in the future. Having studio time before my next class will help me hone my skills and with your help, I can save my money over the next few months to save for the next class (costing >$200). Every bit helps! 
The Perks! 
   If you make a contribution between $5 - $25, I will send you a nice piece of pottery! If you can donate more, I can create and send pottery piece(s) of your suggestion. It can be piece you would like to have custom made for a gift or a functional piece for your home. What are your favorite earthy colors? I can glaze to colors of your interest as well! 

Other Ways You Can Help

   If you cannot contribute, that's OK! It doesn't mean you cannot help. Spread the word or come to an art showing that I hope to have in the future. Your positive energy is already investing in my pursuit of pottery!


Be well folks and embrace your passions!

story:
E|MERGE Interdisciplinary Artist Residency at EARTHDANCE, in Plainfield, MA is entering its 4th year—bringing together 30-40 artists of multiple disciplines for a ground-breaking, collaborative residency: part think-tank, part lab, part workshop, part performance festival.  Forging new ground in cross-disciplinary performance, while successfully building a dynamic and powerful interdisciplinary artist network!

Local, national and international artists work in dance studios, cabins on the land, and in loft spaces,  kitchens, attics and the great outdoors. They create installations, film, audience interactive work, dance, theater, music and genre-busting contemporary performance.

Your contribution will go to support this year's Artists-in-Residence in the form of need based scholarships.

We've organized this campaign as a way to raise money for those artists who cannot afford the fee that covers their room and board for the residency.  By contributing to the campaign you're ensuring that E|MERGE remains accessible to fabulous artists regaurdless of their ability to pay.  In addition to this, if we raise enough money we will be able to start an E|MERGE Fund, that will go to support the longevity of this incredible interdisciplinary residency.

E|MERGE is the only artist residency program of its kind in the country!

E|MERGE a unique residency, has been growing since its founding in 2012, into a national and international network of highly skilled artists who continue to support and develop one another’s work, beyond the residency itself.

The residency lasts two full weeks, to give the artists focused project work time. The residency time-line is incredibly intensive. This year, we will focus specific attention on the art of collaboration. Initial workshops and round table discussions will engage various strategies, structures, and techniques of collaboration. 

Resident artists receive staff support, housing, food, unlimited studio time, workshops, and a performance production.  An artist fee covers food expenses for the artists, but the residency is otherwise subsidized by Earthdance and reliant on funders and your support! Artist fees do not cover staff, housing, space usage and other expenses.

That's where you come in....Help us to sustain this project.  Make a pledge today!

While E|MERGE has been an incredible success for the artists in supporting the vibrant mission and environment that Earthdance provides, Earthdance does not currently have funding for this program.  We remain committed to subsidizing this residency for artists, who already have the expenses of travel and time without income for 14 days. We are committed to providing this crucial time and space to hard-working artists and building a fund to support the residency into the coming years.

HELP US MEET OUR EXPENSES, WHILE KEEPING THIS UNIQUE RESIDENCY AFFORDABLE FOR ARTISTS  BY PLEDGING GENEROUSLY

Here’s what some past E|MERGE artist residents have to say:

Thank you [E|MERGE] for reminding me what it means to create from a place of joy and laughter rather than stress and frustration. 

— Gillian Chadsey, actor/performer (New York)

The two weeks were very inspiring. Fascinating encounters happened within the projects and workshops, but also around them in various informal exchanges - and I do not mean only with each individual, but also in relation to the kind of collective that arised from our gathering at earthdance.

— Akseli Aittomäki, dancer (Finland) 

This residency is a wonderful dream, just keep it going...                

— Pamela Casper, sculptor (New York)

E|MERGE is one of the most innovative arts residencies imaginable. It is incredible to have at one's disposal, a group of exquisitely talented interdisciplinary artists who not only have skills, but also have concentrated space and time to work together. The collaborations that result are unique and surprisingly unpredictable... As an artist the Emerge residency gave me both the resources and the time to create what would not have been possible to create elsewhere. The place became as much a part of the content of what was created as the content of the piece itself.

— Kristen Greco, choreographer (San Francisco)

Artists are meant to learn from each other, and to defy the hierarchical relationships that have perpetuated mentor/student dysfunction, internalized oppression, isolation, etc. E|MERGE presented a model for interrogating those relationships, breaking them apart, and re-forming them in new ways.

— Emmy Bean, actor/singer/puppeteer (Chicago)

 

THANK YOU TO SOME OF OUR GENEROUS E|MERGE ARTISTS FOR THE FOLLOWING PERKS:

-TARA RYNDERS will film her audience interactive, one-on-one dance project during the E|MERGE 2013 residency of her own work and put it on DVD.  For more information on this ground-breaking project, visit: http://www.tararynders.net/you-and-me

- NEW DANCE ALLIANCE Director KAREN BERNARD has offered studio space in New Dance Alliance’s rehearsal studio on 182 Duane Street in Tribeca. The studio is 23' x 30' with 10-1/2' wall height to ceiling, sprung wood-floor, 2 large windows, mirrors with a curtain, VHS player and monitor, stereo system, trapeze point, scrim, ceiling fans and air conditioning. Learn more at: www.newdancealliance.org

- LEXA WALSH and Toychestra (all-woman experimental music group from Oakland, California) offered CD's! Check them out at www.Toychestra.com!

- STEPHANIE TROTTER and brother Nick called Trotter/Trotter's first record release, It is enough to become an instrument, broaches the tropes of Pop Music, Opera, Electronic Music, and Free Improv. The EP is 58-minutes with liner notes featuring original artwork.

- GREGOR KRAMMER, voguer, piano player, all around creative is making a cartoony drawing of a woman on a motorbike called “Little Red Riding through the Woods,"  inspired by the work of Alfons Mucha and will be framed.

- MEMO will make a unique sculpture with attention to preferences from the donor. To see a selection of his works online, visit http://www.memosworld.com/gallery/.

- SIMON HANUKAI, based in New York City, has offered a three-hour group workshop on theater for up to twenty people! As the winner of this perk, you may choose among “using theater as a tool for social change,” “intro to theater of the oppressed techniques,” or “intro into viewpoints- theatrical composition.” Theater experience is not necessary and the workshop will be conducted in the location of the donors choice as long as transportation costs are covered. 

This year's residents include:

Andy Lundberg
Anna Sophie Malmberg
Audrey Beth Stein
Catherine Mueller
CJ Holm
Cory Neale
Elizabeth June Bergman
Elizabeth MacKinnon
Gregor Krammer
Joan Schwartz
Kelsey Hobbs
Kevin Dockery
Laurel Koop
Leanne Dyer
Leslie Castellano-Howabauten
Lexa Walsh
Mariel Berger
Maya Urbanowitz
Meara McGinniss
Memo
Michael Pope
Miriam Woolodarski
Nicole Nigro
Nyx Zierhut
Phoebe Osborne
Rosemary Hannon
Saliq Savage
Samina Bazai
Shira Lynn
Simon Hanukai
Stephanie Lavon Trotter
Tara Rynder
Thea Patterson

story:
To continue donating, please visit our Pasadena Arts Council page at the following site:

http://www.pasadenaartscouncil.org/emerge/insta...

Thank you for your interest in INSTALL:WeHo. We hope you will take a few minutes to look over the video and read the information below. INSTALL:WeHo is the beginning of a new arts initiative that centers around the support and growth of young, emerging artists and performers in the LGBTQ community. By supporting INSTALL, you are empowering a vital group of people to share their voice and their vision. Thank you again for your interest and care in taking the time to visit us!

MISSION

INSTALL:WeHo is an interactive exhibition showcasing the curated and juried work of LBGTQ-minded artists in the Greater Los Angeles community. With the support of the City of West Hollywood, ONE National Gay & Lesbian Archives, Los Angeles Contemporary Exhibitions and Pasadena Arts Council, this pop-up installation will serve as a forum to bring both established and emerging LGBTQ artists and contributors together. In the raw, spontaneous spirit of the underground art scene and with the refined organization of a fine art biennial, INSTALL:WeHo will appear overnight in a caravan of U-­Haul trucks. Each dedicated to, and curated by an individual, organization, gallery or performance troupe, but together forming a pop-­up art "city." In doing so, INSTALL:WeHo has the opportunity to share the story, struggles and spirits of our community at large through a diverse array of mediums and forms.

HOW YOU CAN HELP

INSTALL is now trying to raise funds for our inaugural event. This money will go towards grants for the artists we will jury to show on September 16. The ongoing mission of INSTALL:WeHo is to provide a platform and voice for the emerging LGBTQ artists that might not have otherwise had the chace to show their work on a larger level. 

While INSTALL:WeHo is a one-day event, the larger goal of the organization is to create an ongoing fund for artists. We hope to become a non-profit that can continually partner with artists and organizations who share our common interest in supporting the art and LGBTQ community. INSTALL will become an annual event as well - offering a fresh look every year at the artists and performers who shape our community today and in the future.

WHY

Today, the LGBTQ Civil Rights movement is moving at an increasing pace. At a time where social/political/historical change is happening rapidly within the LGBTQ community, it is imperative to give our artists a voice. Artists and performers offer a social and emotional context and interpretation for the events taking place around us. It is our hope that by providing grants and showing the works of these voices, we will not only support growth within art community, but we will contribute to the historic documentation of what's to come.

WANT TO KNOW MORE?

If you're interested in helping in other ways or are being considered as an artist/performer for INSTALL:WeHo, please email the team at installweho@gmail.com to get connected.

INSTALL:WeHo is a project  of the Pasadena Arts Council’s EMERGE Fiscal Sponsorship Program

Additional Thanks to Our Sponsors

City of West Hollywood, ONE National Gay and Lesbian Archives, Los Angeles Contemporary Exhibitions
story_txt:
To continue donating, please visit our Pasadena Arts Council page at the following site:
http://www.pasadenaartscouncil.org/emerge/insta...
Thank you for your interest in INSTALL:WeHo. We hope you will take a few minutes to look over the video and read the information below. INSTALL:WeHo is the beginning of a new arts initiative that centers around the support and growth of young, emerging artists and performers in the LGBTQ community. By supporting INSTALL, you are empowering a vital group of people to share their voice and their vision. Thank you again for your interest and care in taking the time to visit us!

story:
Durham Arts Council Emerging Artist Grant Program 2012-13

Investing in Human Creativity

Durham Arts Council seeks your partnership and investment to help launch and develop the careers of highly skilled and promising artists who have mastered the basics of their discipline, and are at a critical development moment in their artistic lives where they need funding, encouragement, and recognition of their work.  The DAC's Emerging Artist Program serves artists in visual, performing, literary, and media arts in five North Carolina counties in the central Piedmont area and has been a vital part of developing artist careers for 29 years.

Each year, 12-16 grants are awarded to artists selected from a highly competitive applicant pool of over 100 artists who apply from Durham, Chatham, Orange, Granville and Person counties.  Each grant of approximately $1,500 funds a project pivotal to the advancement of the artist’s work.

“Any kind of support for artists is crucial, but it is especially important at points in their careers where they are either emerging or branching out in new directions.  By providing funding during moments of change and growth, the Emerging Artists Program encourages diversity and contributes greatly to the richness of life and culture in the whole state.”  Roger Manley, photographer, film director, curator, Director of the Gregg Museum of Art and Design, Emerging Artist grant recipient 1987-88

In 2013 DAC has chosen 16 artists to receive grants.  We are working to raise $7,500 to match grants received from the North Carolina Arts Council and The Mary Duke Biddle Foundation.

The following artists have been selected to receive grants in 2013:

Nadjib Adebola Assani, film/video: Create an animated trailer to promote his fantasy series Legends of Onile and expand his range of skills

Christiana Barnett-Murphy, dance: Produce first performance of her choreography in a theatrical setting

Lamine “Diali” Cissokho, music: Make professionally mastered demo-CD and a professional electronic press kit to use to establish his career as solo musician.

Howard L. Craft, drama: Present a staged public reading of his new play, Malcolm and Alex.

Renee Alexander Craft, literature: Create an online book trailer to promote her children’s book.  I will Love You Everywhere Always

Stacy Crabill, painting: Produce ten large scale paintings (4’ x 5’)

Rinku Bhattacharya Das, dance: Study with Manipuri dance guru, Padmashri Darshana Jhaveri, to master the rhythms, technique and compositions of this endangered classical Indian dance form.

Jessica Dupuis, ceramics: Travel and ship work to Houston, TX to install work in two group shows that will take place in conjunction with the 2013 National Council on Education for the Ceramic Arts Conference.

Sarah Goetz, installation: Rent a large dedicated space in which to create an interactive installation in a venue that allows the viewer to become immersed in the experience.

Kenneth Jackson, photography: Purchase equipment to outfit a darkroom/studio.

Stacey L. Kirby, installation: Support for performance of VALIDnation, her new on-going interactive performance installation at ELSEWHERE COLLABORATIVE in Greensboro, NC.

Eric B. Martin, literature: Conclude research and write first draft of non-fiction book, Living While Dying.

Suzanne Rousso, music: Attend Oberlin College Baroque music institute workshop.

Aya Shabu, dance: Develop choreographic skills to create movement for actors by taking classes at ADF in composition and improvisation.

Dan VanHoozer, drama: Attend a workshop in experimental theatre technique led by internationally renowned artist Ant Hampton at the 2013 Fusebox Festival in Austin, TX.

Debra Wuliger, painting: Create Coffee and Connections, a series of paintings exploring the relationships between people and their surroundings in area coffee shops.

 

A sampling of exciting past projects and artists receiving Emerging Artists Grants:

  •  Nnenna Freelon – 6 time Grammy nominated jazz vocalist and arts educator – Emerging Artist Grant 1989-90 -  to purchase recording equipment for her arts education work with elementary school children. 
  • Nicholas Kitchen – world-renowned violinist and founding member of the Borromeo String Quartet – Emerging Artist Grant 1985-86- to cover expenses for travel to the Northern Milstein masterclasses in Zurich. 
  • Beverly McIver – Painter and Suntrust Endowed Chair Professor of Art at North Carolina Central University, recipient of aip John Simon Guggenheim Fellowship and a Radcliffe Fellowship from Harvard University -Emerging Artist Grant 1993-1994 - to attend a residency with the visual artist Alex Katz at the Atlantic Center for the Arts in New Smyrna Beach, Florida
  • Jaki Shelton Green - Poet and playwright, recipient of the 2003 North Carolina Award in Literature -Emerging Artist Grant 1991-1992 and 1999-2000- to complete a publish an in-progress novel.

The Emerging Artist Program over 29 years has funded 435 artist grants totaling $461,356.  The program is also supported by a grant from The Mary Duke Biddle Foundation, and a Regional Artist Project Grant from the North Carolina Arts Council, a division of the NC Department of Cultural Resources.  All funds received in this campaign will go directly to fund the Ella Fountain Pratt Emerging Artist Awards.  Each artist receiving a grant will be recognized at the annual Emerging Artists Awards Ceremony on February 21, 2013.

Each campaign supporter of $50 or more through Indiegogo will receive a complimentary invitation to the awards ceremony.

For more information about the Emerging Artist Program and Durham Arts Council please visit our Emerging Artist Grant page. The Durham Arts Council is a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization that has been creating community through the arts for 58 years.

story:
Summary

I bought myself a 73 Super Beetle for my 24th Birthday and am trying to restore it.  It’s an old rusty beat up thing that barely runs.  I knew NOTHING about cars before the purchase, but I’ve been working on it and learning.

What It Needs

Tons of stuff, bumpers, new fenders, new wheels, tires, engine work, etc.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share your experience in VWs/restorations. Helpful tips on what to do, ideas on modifications to make, etc

story:
Help Me help Joe-Lynn Design

My name is Byron Rempel, and I draw Zombies. Many of you might already know me from my artwork and posts on google plus, and quite a few of you have joined the 1000 zombies art project, or purchased original artwork from me. A few months ago I had the pleasure of meeting Carl Brownell, the owner and operator of Joe-Lynn Design, and he introduced me to the amazing world of high quality Giclee prints. He made some prints for me in exchange for drawing his family as zombies and those prints are the best I've ever seen. I'm completely hooked on giclee prints by Carl. The guy puts in a lot of work for each print and it really shows in the quality and feel.

Here's my 9 zombie cats print on the left and Giclee on the right. Notice how much more depth and color they have.

And that brings me to why I'm running this campaign. Carl needs our help. Recently he's suffered a few weeks of poor sales and to top it off his printer has stopped working properly for him. He needs replacement parts soon or he risks going out of business. 

So I'm taking it on myself to try to help him. I don't want him to stop making Giclee's because I want him to make more of mine. By helping to fund this campaign we can help get Carl his replacement parts, and give him a big order that will help his business and his family too.

On top of helping his business you are also helping out his family. Lately things have been hard on his family and I would really like raise enough funds to make sure he can give his daughters a happy Christmas.

And as an added bonus you help me feel awesome and you gain karma points. You'll need those karma points when the zombie apocalypse really happens too ... so act today. ;)

Where does the money go?

The main reason for this campaign is to raise money to help Carl buy replacement parts for his Epson 7880 Stylus Pro printer. He needs a new print head which will cost between $800-$1500. Carl is actively looking for the best deal. He also needs a maintenance tank which will run about $100. And then he needs some business, which is where we come in by 100 prints from him.

100 prints X at least $20 per print = $2000

And then there's the cost for shipping. We're pricing this with shipping in mind, and Byron is going to kick in a bit for some of that too. If you feel like contributing more to help cover that cost, feel free to do so.


The Perks!

The main perk of this campaign is the 100 limited edition prints of my zombie minions. They are all signed and numbered ... and stamped with my bloody fingerprint.

The prints are 18" wide and 7" high, printed on a fine art paper called Verona 250 HD Cotton Rag Ultra Smooth using Epson K3 inks and then clear coated with UV protection. These giclees are made using the finest materials to date and will last a lifetime.

Other perks include 10x13 giclee prints of anything in Byron's gallery. Inclusion in the 1000 zombies art project, and even owning some original one of a kind zombie art.

So the money will be used to fix his printer, and print the prints. That means paper and inks will be needed. Any money left over will be going towards more paper and inks, additional supplies to help his business.

I'll also need to buy band-aids.


New Perk added ... a 3 panel Wolf print from Carls amazing photographs.
Measures 30"wide and 20"high, comes ready to hang.
FREE SHIPPING IN NORTH AMERICA

ZOMBIE 6 PACK PERK



There will be stretch goals for backers of $50 or more if the goals are met ... so help spread the word and lets get Carl back on track.

The Impact

By contributing to this campaign and helping reach the stretch goals you are helping Carl and his family stay afloat, have a great christmas and you get a one of a kind unique piece of art. 

The work and dedication Carl puts in to his prints will be clear the moment you see them in real life. When I first saw them I was blown away. I don't want to see this guy lose his business and I don't want the world to lose a print craftsman. He also does custom frame work and can make some gorgeous frames for anyone.

Those that know me know I am always trying to help others and share my zombie drawings with the world and I am putting 100% in to getting the project fully funded, and get Carl to make these prints.

Other Ways You Can Help

I know a lot of people are having tough economic times, myself included. So if you can't donate to help Carl fix his printer and save his business, you can help by spreading the word on facebook or twitter and especially google+. Indiegogo has some tools to help share the project too, so check them out.

And if you are on G+ ... look me up and say hi. :)

Thanks for reading this and huge thanks for any help.

story:
An Update (9/22/2015):

My house has come a looong ways since I began this fundraising campaign and thank you all for your support in helping me make that happen. And, it still has a loong ways to go! Please click on the updates tab above to see pictures of where I am at now with my build. In the first round of fundraising I raised around $10,000 if I include the offline donations I received. That was a super helpful boost to get this project started. And through continuing to work helping other people build their own dream houses and setting money aside I still have almost $8,000 in my "tiny house" savings account. But as of late September, 2015 I have decided to take a leave from my work to focus full time on my house, hopefully until it is done. But to do this means that I will need continued financial support and so I am doing a second round of fundraising. So here we go! Will you help me complete this labor of love and make it the masterpiece that I know it can be? 

So far I have spent about $12,000 on the house and lived on a very tight budget of just under $1000 a month for my own personal needs. I expect that the whole project will cost around $25,000 when it is said and done, plus hundreds and hundreds of hours in free labor of my and family and friends. It is an art project, exploring the ideas of physical space, community, and shelter... and I am the artist. If you can see the value of this project as community art I hope you will consider funding me to complete this project. Thank you!

About Me:


Hello! My name is Miwa and I am a young, aspiring female builder. My journey into the building world began four years ago when I first dreamed of building my own home. After working on a bunch of natural building projects, doing a timber frame apprenticeship at The Heartwood School, and learning about more conventional construction on the job, I am finally embarking on building my own Tiny Home. I am excited for the opportunity to build my own sacred space and to integrate all that I have learned in the last four years. I want to create a beautiful, affordable, and environmentally friendly home and then be able to share all that I have learned with others!

I see building this home as literally and metaphorically building a solid foundation for myself. I am learning a ton and know that all this knowledge will allow me to better serve others later. Beyond just being my home, I hope this tiny home will  show people what is possible and inspire them to go for their dreams. So please consider helping me with this labor of love so I can get on to the more important business of helping others manifest their dreams!  My goal is to have my home ready to move into by January 2016. To do this I need your help! 

Help me build a home that SHINES with community LOVE

These tiny homes tend to cost most people $20,000 - $30,000 in materials to build. That is more money than I have ever had in the bank! I hope to build mine for less, but I do not want to sacrifice quality to do that. I have already put $5000 into this home and and have only $3000 left in savings. My plan is to continue working, paying for things as I go, but your donations will help provide the financial buffer for me to really put my time, energy and Love into this house. 

In particular, you will help insure that I can continue to choose environmentally friendly, non toxic, local, and salvaged materials whenever possible, and be able to add the creative and artistic touches that will make this home SHINE with community LOVE. 

In my mind my tiny house has a circular stained glass window of interlocking hearts, similar to the image below, that is made either by me or a local artisan. This and other artistic touches are ones that will cost a little extra money. I hope you will help me pursue these important details that will make my home truly sing with beauty!


Other specific things your money will help make possible: 

  • The setting up of a solar power system bought from the Ecovillage @ Ithaca that will allow me to power this build using solar power! 
  • The use of rockwool (brand name Roxul) as a natural mineral fiber insulation 
  • Buying of materials from local small businesses, such as Cayuga lumber, Collins Lumber Mill, and Locke Enterprises.
  • Help cover the costs of taking a cabinet making course at the Heartwood School, which I hope will give me the skills to tackle much of the interior finish work on my tiny house 
  • As part of choosing to live simply and with a small environmental footprint I do not own a car. And finding creative ways to get around, including biking, walking, and carpooling is something I usually love doing. But occasionally as a builder I do need to rent or borrow a truck or other vehicles. Help me cover these transportation costs and compensate my friends for the use of their cars.

    The Impact

    I already feel the groundswell of enthusiasm and support around "Tiny Houses" and their potential to inspire and free people to live their dreams. When I decided to go forth with this project my friend Amy decided she wanted one too. So we actually bought our trailers together, and the planning for her house is already in the works! 
    At the core of this dream for me is a belief that the creation of a safe, stable, and sacred space that is "home" is a powerful metaphor for many, including myself. Through the outward, physical manifestation of such a space, much inner healing can happen. That is a gift I want to share with others. 

      Risks & Challenges

      The process has already begun. I am committed to building my home, one way or another. Now it is a question of whether or not I will have to cut corners and sacrifice quality or artistic elements in order to complete my home. Your donations will also help determine whether or not I will be able to pour most of my energy into this, as I want to, or if I will have to split my time working other jobs to allow me to keep moving forward. A financial buffer will make the whole process more enjoyable. For example, it will give me the funds to treat myself and others to a nice hot meal at the end of a hard day's work! 

      Will you help me manifest this dream to its fullest potential?

        How to Donate

        SImply click on the Donate button up above on the right to give money using PayPal or a credit card. Or, if you prefer you can send a check directly to me. Just send me an e-mail to get my mailing address: miwarobbins@gmail.com

        My stated goal is $7,000 and I hope you will help me reach it, as indiegogo takes an additional 5% penalty for not reaching your goal. My super goal, which I think would allow me to truly relax and sink into my artistic process with this project, is $12,000. If I reach this goal through on and offline donations I will be ecstatic! 


        Other Ways You Can Help

        If you can't contribute money there are many other ways you can get involved. Here are just a few ideas:

        • Come and help out for a day! Or two or three.... Or just come out to say hi. I like getting visitors and it is a great opportunity for you to learn. And it is often a huge help for me just to have the extra hands.
        • Donate materials. For now I am looking mostly for raw building materials, like lumber, screws and nails, and a few small windows. I am also on the look out for a small wood stove, an efficient medium sized fridge, a farm style sink for the kitchen and a cute little sink for the bathroom, among other things. If you have something you think I could use let me know!
        • Offer your vehicle for the occasional or more long term loan! Having friends with trucks is always handy. I don't own a car at all and am hoping to be able to do this tiny house project without having to buy one, which is proving to be trickier as the weather gets colder. If you are going on vacation or have a second car you rarely use that you would consider loaning or renting to me at a low cost for some or all of the winter, please let me know!  
        • Offer your skills! Do you have some special craftsmanship skills that you feel moved to offer? I want this house to shine with community love, which means lots of special artistic touches left by the many hands that will be involved. Consider it an opportunity to get your art out into the world and help beautify a home that I hope many people will pass through.
        • Help spread the word by sharing this campaign via facebook, twitter, e-mail, and, of course, word of mouth! 
        And last, but certainly not least, I cannot do this without the support of my community, and such support can come in many forms. Just your shared enthusiasm for this project means A LOT to me! (Especially on those days when it is cold and wet and I am having trouble finding my own enthusiasm.) So if this project excites you please let me know! Friend me on facebook to get picture updates and/or consider following my blog to get a more in depth, if less frequent account of my journey. Blessings to you all and may we all be able to make our dreams come true.
story_txt:
An Update (9/22/2015):
My house has come a looong ways since I began this fundraising campaign and thank you all for your support in helping me make that happen. And, it still has a loong ways to go! Please click on the updates tab above to see pictures of where I am at now with my build. In the first round of fundraising I raised around $10,000 if I include the offline donations I received. That was a super helpful boost to get this project started. And through continuing to work helping other people build their own dream houses and setting money aside I still have almost $8,000 in my "tiny house" savings account. But as of late September, 2015 I have decided to take a leave from my work to focus full time on my house, hopefully until it is done. But to do this means that I will need continued financial support and so I am doing a second round of fundraising. So here we go! Will you help me complete this labor of love and make it the masterpiece that I know it can be? 

So far I have spent about $12,000 on the house and lived on a very tight budget of just under $1000 a month for my own personal needs. I expect that the whole project will cost around $25,000 when it is said and done, plus hundreds and hundreds of hours in free labor of my and family and friends. It is an art project, exploring the ideas of physical space, community, and shelter... and I am the artist. If you can see the value of this project as community art I hope you will consider funding me to complete this project. Thank you!

About Me:



Hello! My name is Miwa and I am a young, aspiring female builder. My journey into the building world began four years ago when I first dreamed of building my own home. After working on a bunch of natural building projects, doing a timber frame apprenticeship at The Heartwood School, and learning about more conventional construction on the job, I am finally embarking on building my own Tiny Home. I am excited for the opportunity to build my own sacred space and to integrate all that I have learned in the last four years. I want to create a beautiful, affordable, and environmentally friendly home and then be able to share all that I have learned with others!
I see building this home as literally and metaphorically building a solid foundation for myself. I am learning a ton and know that all this knowledge will allow me to better serve others later. Beyond just being my home, I hope this tiny home will  show people what is possible and inspire them to go for their dreams. So please consider helping me with this labor of love so I can get on to the more important business of helping others manifest their dreams!  My goal is to have my home ready to move into by January 2016. To do this I need your help!    Help me build a home that SHINES with community LOVE These tiny homes tend to cost most people $20,000 - $30,000 in materials to build. That is more money than I have ever had in the bank! I hope to build mine for less, but I do not want to sacrifice quality to do that. I have already put $5000 into this home and and have only $3000 left in savings. My plan is to continue working, paying for things as I go, but your donations will help provide the financial buffer for me to really put my time, energy and Love into this house. 
In particular, you will help insure that I can continue to choose environmentally friendly, non toxic, local, and salvaged materials whenever possible, and be able to add the creative and artistic touches that will make this home SHINE with community LOVE. 
In my mind my tiny house has a circular stained glass window of interlocking hearts, similar to the image below, that is made either by me or a local artisan. This and other artistic touches are ones that will cost a little extra money. I hope you will help me pursue these important details that will make my home truly sing with beauty!




Other specific things your money will help make possible: 


The setting up of a solar power system bought from the Ecovillage @ Ithaca that will allow me to power this build using solar power! 

The use of rockwool (brand name Roxul) as a natural mineral fiber insulation 
Buying of materials from local small businesses, such as Cayuga lumber, Collins Lumber Mill, and Locke Enterprises.
Help cover the costs of taking a cabinet making course at the Heartwood School, which I hope will give me the skills to tackle much of the interior finish work on my tiny house 
As part of choosing to live simply and with a small environmental footprint I do not own a car. And finding creative ways to get around, including biking, walking, and carpooling is something I usually love doing. But occasionally as a builder I do need to rent or borrow a truck or other vehicles. Help me cover these transportation costs and compensate my friends for the use of their cars.


  The Impact
I already feel the groundswell of enthusiasm and support around "Tiny Houses" and their potential to inspire and free people to live their dreams. When I decided to go forth with this project my friend Amy decided she wanted one too. So we actually bought our trailers together, and the planning for her house is already in the works! 
At the core of this dream for me is a belief that the creation of a safe, stable, and sacred space that is "home" is a powerful metaphor for many, including myself. Through the outward, physical manifestation of such a space, much inner healing can happen. That is a gift I want to share with others. 


  Risks & Challenges The process has already begun. I am committed to building my home, one way or another. Now it is a question of whether or not I will have to cut corners and sacrifice quality or artistic elements in order to complete my home. Your donations will also help determine whether or not I will be able to pour most of my energy into this, as I want to, or if I will have to split my time working other jobs to allow me to keep moving forward. A financial buffer will make the whole process more enjoyable. For example, it will give me the funds to treat myself and others to a nice hot meal at the end of a hard day's work! 
Will you help me manifest this dream to its fullest potential?

  How to Donate
SImply click on the Donate button up above on the right to give money using PayPal or a credit card. Or, if you prefer you can send a check directly to me. Just send me an e-mail to get my mailing address: miwarobbins@gmail.com

My stated goal is $7,000 and I hope you will help me reach it, as indiegogo takes an additional 5% penalty for not reaching your goal. My super goal, which I think would allow me to truly relax and sink into my artistic process with this project, is $12,000. If I reach this goal through on and offline donations I will be ecstatic! 


Other Ways You Can Help
 If you can't contribute money there are many other ways you can get involved. Here are just a few ideas:



Come and help out for a day! Or two or three.... Or just come out to say hi. I like getting visitors and it is a great opportunity for you to learn. And it is often a huge help for me just to have the extra hands.

Donate materials. For now I am looking mostly for raw building materials, like lumber, screws and nails, and a few small windows. I am also on the look out for a small wood stove, an efficient medium sized fridge, a farm style sink for the kitchen and a cute little sink for the bathroom, among other things. If you have something you think I could use let me know!

Offer your vehicle for the occasional or more long term loan! Having friends with trucks is always handy. I don't own a car at all and am hoping to be able to do this tiny house project without having to buy one, which is proving to be trickier as the weather gets colder. If you are going on vacation or have a second car you rarely use that you would consider loaning or renting to me at a low cost for some or all of the winter, please let me know!  


Offer your skills! Do you have some special craftsmanship skills that you feel moved to offer? I want this house to shine with community love, which means lots of special artistic touches left by the many hands that will be involved. Consider it an opportunity to get your art out into the world and help beautify a home that I hope many people will pass through.
Help spread the word by sharing this campaign via facebook, twitter, e-mail, and, of course, word of mouth! 

And last, but certainly not least, I cannot do this without the support of my community, and such support can come in many forms. Just your shared enthusiasm for this project means A LOT to me! (Especially on those days when it is cold and wet and I am having trouble finding my own enthusiasm.) So if this project excites you please let me know! Friend me on facebook to get picture updates and/or consider following my blog to get a more in depth, if less frequent account of my journey. Blessings to you all and may we all be able to make our dreams come true.

story:
Hello, my name is Robert and my partner in this campaign is named Jack. We are just two college students trying to start our own business in 3D design. Our goal is to have people be able to get a completely unique case for their phone, or a cool piece of art for their room. We want people to be able to be creative and create their own piece of art from their computer.


    With the money from this campaign we will buy: A Makerbot Replicator 2X dual color printer $2,500, the replacement plan $500, different colors of ABS and PLA filament ~$700, A computer to run the 3D software, ~ $1,500, supplies to maintenance the printer $100, price to hire a web designer to make our website $1,000-$2,000, tax for everything ~$500.


    This business is important to us because its a way to let people express themselves. The ability to show off their own creations would be amazing. People are all creative in their own ways and this would be an easy way for people to express their thoughts in a creation that they made.


    I think we will be able to overcome the challenges of providing an easy way for everyone to become designers and inventors. One of the main risks involved is financing the printer but with your help we will be able to do it!


    If you enjoy the idea but aren't able to donate, You can always share this with your friends and family. No matter how you support us, from the bottom of our hearts, thank you!

story:
C&Rsenal has spent the past two years tinkering at our WWII Anatomy Project.  As time has passed we've perfected the presentation and included some great classic designs.  Now we're ready to speed things up by launching a bulk purchase of posters.

For this project we've combined the first eight photo sets of disassembled pistols into one clean, crisp poster.  Each pistol is labelled for identification and backed by a national symbol representing its place in the war.  These are high resolution photos that give a great insight into the design, manufacture, industrial capacity, and overall expectations for combat of the nations involved.

These posters were created using pieces borrowed from museums and private collectors and each pistol has at least ten hours of craft involved to research, photograph, disassemble, photograph again (each single part), reassemble, and digitally edit to perfection.  We're confident they will attract the interest of fans of history, guns, engineering, or militaria. 

Thanks for your help!


What We Need & What You Get

We just need some cash in hand so we can bulk order some posters and drive the cost down for you guys! 

What you get is, well a sweet poster!

Risks & Challenges

Luckily we've chosen a very simple project to start with.  We've pre-priced the bulk order of the posters and shipping tubes and factored in the time and expense to ship to our supporters.

We are going to attempt to deliver before Christmas, which is the only expectation prone to failure.  Assuming our printing source upholds their delivery guarantees our short, 20-day campaign should be over in time.  If not, I do apologize in advance for new year deliveries.  BUT you kick in and you will get a poster.  We've been shipping individual requests and prints for over a year now so very few curveballs left.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't want to drop any money on this poster please do keep following us at C&Rsenal.  Share our images and articles widely.  Our good name is going to be what gets us in to more and more museums and collections and will keep the photos coming.

Share this campaign especially as it is our first attempt at crowd sourcing.
